div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: From the Border.
div3.p:
There was an nows of speculation, received from the army near Fredericksburg yesterday.
It was rumored in camp that the Federal army had returned to Alexandria, with a view to take up winter quarters at that point.

The Central train brought down from Staunton, last evening twenty four Yankee prisoners, whose capture by Capt. McNeill, is Hardy county, we have here Store noticed.
Among the party was the Pierpont sheriff of Barbour county, who we liars, has been very active in carrying out the honest of his Yankee masters in that county, and in collecting revenue from the people to support the hireling of Lincoln in their crusade upon the loyal citizens of the Northwest.

div3.head: Eastern North Carolina.
div3.p:
The latest information which reaches us from the coast of North Carolina dispels every doubt teat the enemy are concentrating in heavy force, with a view to strike a blow at the main line of railway on nearing Richmond with the for South.
It is stated that their forces at Newborn and Moore head City, on the coast, number from 50,000 to 70,000 and that they are evidently preparing for a forward movement.
It is also represented that a powerful fleet is now in rendezvous at Morehead City, with a view to an early naval attack upon Wilmington.
It is believed that a simultaneous movement will be made upon Weldon or some other supposed accessible point on the great Southern railway.
The North Carolina papers indicate a manifest uneasiness not only for Wilmington and the country east of Raleigh, but even for the safety of the capital itself.

div3.head: The Murfreesboro' battle.
div3.p: As time passes, and the confusion which succeeds a determined struggle clears away, we are furnished ample evidence of the decided adventure obtained by our remain the battle in front of Murfreesboro'. The correct statistics of the combats of Wednesday and Friday, may be summed up as follows:

row.cell: enemy's loss in killed and wounded

div3.p:
In addition to these statistics, which relate only to the two days struggle mentioned large quantities of provisions and supplies have been procured in Middle Tennessee, amounting to millions of rations and months of subsistence.
That portion of the campaign which constituted Murfreesboro' its depot has terminated, leaving us much to hope for and little to deplore, except the temporary surrender of a comparatively small portion of territory.
Tullahoma the position now occupied by General Bragg's army, is in Coffee county Tone.
situated on Rock Creek, and offers admirable means of defence.
It is 71 miles from Nashville, and 32 from Murfreesboro', and lies immediately on the Nashville and Chattanooga railroad where it is intersected by the McMinnville and Manchester road.--As a lose of operations and as a position of defence, it offers great advantages.

div3.head: Payment of the Alabama State debt.
div3.p: --The Mobiles Register, of Sunday, says:

q.p:
A British war steamer is expected to arrive in our bay to-day; the object of her late visit Leading to communicate with the British Consul, and to receive the interest on the Alabama State dept and to foreign bondholders.
The amount is £40,000 sterling, and is ready for payment in gold.

div3.head: A Negro soldier Scot.
div3.p: --Joseph, member of Company Crist Regiment on Battle Guards (negroes,) of Louisiana, was shot in Crisans on the 10th inst. for disobedience to his Lieutenant.

Specie and Bank Notes--Since our last report specie has declined.
The brokens are now offering only $1.75@1.80 for gold and selling at $2 @1.05.
For silver they are offering $1.50 and seizing $1.50. The amount of coin offering is increasing and a further decline in anticipated.
This decline fiscals fly owing to the increased amount of Stalling Exchange in the market, which the brokers are selling at $8.12 ½ prem.
Fartios who here remitted and sold Confederates, bonds abroad at a comparatively small discount, can afford to and rabid the speciate rates, and while this competition excels the premium for specie will be liable to further decline.
Virginia and North Carolina bank notes are firm at last quotations.

Bonds and Stocks.--The demand for Confederate bonds (100 mts) is improving whilst the disposition to invest in State Stocks seems to be less active.
From recent sales we quote Confederate bonds at par and int — brokers, offering 99½ @22d.
Virginia 6's registered 110--dull; North Carolina do 131--a decline; do eights 116 and int; city of Petersburg bond; 126 and int; South side R R deguared 128 and int; Va Cent E R bonds 1st most 112; va and Tenn R R do, 2d most, 110; Va Cent R R track 75', R and Y R R do 50; B'R of Com do 15--in advance; Farmers' B'k 163 firm; inst Co State of Va 21½

Real Estate.--There have been no sales of importance this week.
Two desirable dwellings in Grace, near 18th street offered Thursday afternoon, were withdrawn the hide being below the owner's views.
The usual announcement at this period, that "the taxes for the present year will be paid by the purchaser," will induce more caution on the part of buyers until the probable action of Congress and the State Legislature in respect to taxation for 1863 is developed.

div4.p:
In the line of Groceries and Produce everything is advancing, except Salt.
We append the whole sale quotations, from which the reader may ascertain the prices of various articles or merchandise at the stores as well as at auctions:
Provisions,--Bacon — Hoground, 61@75c; Harce; 80c; Butter, in packages, $1.25@1.25; Lard, 70@75c; Cheese $1.15@1.50.

Groceries.--Brown Sugar; $1; Refined, $1.25@1.25; Molasses is very scarce and sells by auction at $1 per gallon; Coffee, $3.80@4; Candies, 07; Tea, 6@5; Country Soap, 61@61c, Turpentine do., 90@$1; Rice, 2 @2½ Salt, 25@35; per lb.

Breadstuffs--Flour — Superfine, $20; Extra $21@22; Family, $25@25; Corn Meal, $3.50 bushel; Wheat — the Government agent is paying but $3.50 and this seems to be the starting price at the mills for prime white and red. The mills have not yet fully commenced operation.
The market is unsettled.
Corn, $1.50 per bushel'; Hye $3@3.50 per bushel.

Miscellaneous--Apples are going up, and we quote to day $35 @45 per barrel; and in dement; Dried Apple, $5@5.50 per bushel; Dried Peaches $5 @$10; Rev. 15 per 10 cwt; Baled Cats, $7; Onfous, $10@50 per bbl; Potatoes--Irish, $4@ Sweet 7@8 per bushel, and very scarce.
Bread-- Pilot, 14c; Water Crackers, 16c; Soda Cracker $6c per 15.

Liquor.--Notional.
The tendency is to We quote Whiskey at $25@25;Apply brisk at $20; and French Brandy, (but lit to market,) at $50.
Messrs Robinson Adams & Co's sale on following prices were obtained:

Orleans Sugar, in hhds, do, in bbls.
sugar, $1.29@1.25; Crushed of 2½ Molasses, $10.75 @ Super Crab

div3.head: Late Northern news.
div3.p:
The telegraph has pretty fully anticipated the news received in our of the intent Northern papers furnished us through the politicoes of Captain Philip Cashmeyer.
The Legislature of Pennsylvania met on the 6th inst, and G. V. Lawrence (Tep) was elected Speaker of the Senate by given majority, and Join Capua (Dem,) was chosen Speaker of the House by a majority of nins.--Both in their addresses, urged the vigorous prosecution of the war. Philadelphia has suffered a severe more furious in the fact that the "Anderson Troop, " a cavalry regiment raised out of the "wealthiest and most respectable young men of the city," refused to go into the Murfreesboro' for alleging that their officers were inexperienced--Gen Bets Gutler it to have a grand banquet in New York this week's the Aster House.

div4.head: The retreat of the Western armies
div4.p:
It will be read from the following which we find in the editorial columns of the Tribune, of Tuesday, that on Saturday night, the very time at which Gen. Bragg retired from Murfreesboro', Rosecrans also made a retrograde movement across and some distance beyond Stone river.
We say "some distance" because it is stated that, although he was apprised of Gen. Bragg's retreat at 7 A. M., be did not move his army back to the river before-evening and did not think of pursuing until Monday morning. The following is the extract from the Tribune:

There are source discrepancies between General Rosecrans accounts of the actions of Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and those heretofore published which future reports will doubtless explain.
On Saturday a heavy fall of rain confined hostile on both sides to indecisive skirmishing on During the day provision and trains reached our army, and put it in condition to assumes the offensive on the next day. The rain having river and the of the brid is across it leaving on the that bank unsupported by the member, Gen Roserrend deemed it prudent to when draw all our troop to the was bank during Saturday night This retrograde movement though required by prudence, was discovered on Sunday morning to have been unnecessary, on account of the evacuation of Murfreesboro' by the enemy in the course of the night.

Gen. Rosecrans was apprised of the retreat at 7 A. M. but could not move his army to the river before evening.
Yesterday morning he expected to cross the river the town, and after the enemy in good The rebel to have back toward Fayetteville, in Green county, on the main road to Northern Alabama.

Whether the movement is a bound compulsory retreat or arise from loss in numbers and spirit, or is merely a change of their line of operation remains to be seen nevertheless, it appears certain that superior outrage and endurance of our troops turned the rebel victory of Wednesday into a defeat on astray.
When we consider that — from cause as yet not fully apparent — in the first day's battle our right was broken eight division and brigade cementers killed, wounded and captured, one-third of our artillery lost, and that, notwithstanding all this and the of provisions and ammunition in consequence of the rebel cavalry raids upon our trains, our troops fought again on two successive days, and fought successfully, we cannot withhold an earnest tribute of praise and admiration from the whole brave army.
They have gloriously demonstrated what persistent pluck will always accomplish.

Gen. Rosencrans's last dispatch is as follows.
It will be seen that, like McClellan, he knows to a dot who is killed and wounded:

div5.p: To Major General H. W. Halleck, General-in-Chief:
We have fought one of the greatest battles of this war and are victorious.
Casantire success on the 31st was prevented by a surprise of the right flank; but we have never then at beaten the enemy after three days fighting.
They fled with great precipitation on Saturday night.

The last of their columns of cavalry left this morning.
Their loss has been very heavy.

Generals Rams and Hanson are killed.
Generals Clardon, Adams and Breckinridge, are wounded

closer.signed: W. S. Rosecrans. Major Gen'l Com'g.

div4.head: The Carnage at Fredericksburg — Graphic account from a Yankee soldier.
div4.p: A participant in the fight at Fredericksburg sends the following letter to a friend in Baltimore, which has found its way into print:

That long expected battle has been fought and we have met the most serious defeat of the war. Being an eye witness in the earlier and a participant in the latter part of the engagement I suppose it will not be out of place for me to give you a brief outline of what fell under my notice.
to gather with a few observations relative to the matter.
During the earlier part of the action our corps remained on the reserve on the east side of the Rappahannock.
Early in the morning climbed a tall tree, from the top of which I had a district view of the scene of battle at its commencement.
After being there attentively occupied for some time, orders came to our division, commanded by General Griffin, to cross the river, and the bugle sound to "fall in" brought me down in double quick, and instead of being a curious spectator.
I soon became a shatter in the fight.
This battle was fought on a remarkable small space of ground.
To the rear of Fredericksburg, that is claiming the front of the city to be on the river, there is a plain of about half a mile in acres, which terminate, in a ridge of steep hill, where the enemy had taken up his position.
This was the plain where Generals Sumner's and Hooker's Grand Divisions fought and attempted to storm those works of the enemy which Gen. Burnside has denominated the "key to their position." From morning till night assault after assault was repeated to gain possession of those heights, but the many desperate efforts of our troops met with failure.
We were defeated because bravery and human endurance were unequal to the undertaking.
When we charged across the open field, the concentrated, withering fire of the enemy swept everything be ore it, and fendered the accomplishment of our purpose an utter impossibility.
Within about one hundred and fifty yards of the of the range of hids there is a slight elevation on this otherwise level field.
To this small knoll we succeeded in advancing, and further it was not possible to go. Some of our best regiments attempted to pass beyond this knoll and charge on the rebel infantry posted a short distance off behind a stone wall but in the attempt were invariably all but annihilated.
This slight rise, although not exceeding five or six feet in height, afforded us a great dealt of shelter and were it not for this advantage we could not have obtained any portion of the field.
It is the prevailing opinion that had the attack been made at any other point we would have had a Glorious victory instead of a shameful defeat.
All that were engaged fought most bravely, and in no battle of the war have our troops displayed greater valor.
There was no panic, no skulking, except now and then an occasional case, nor any other exhibition of cowardice.
Men could not have done better, and wherever the fault belongs it certainly does not rest with the rank and file.
Even the enemy acknowledges this fact.
At nightfall the slaughter ceased.

With the impression that the battle would be renewed the next morning, we lay down on the field among the feed and wounded.
I could not give you any idea of the mortal agony I suffered that night.
After the firing had ceased not having any covering with us at our regiments had left their knapsacks in the city previous is going into action, I searched around in the dark for a Blackett.
After a little search I succeeded in finding two, one of which was quite damp, occasioned as I discovered in the morning, by being saturated with blood,--Sharing these with two of my companions.
I lay down to gain a little rest.
But sleep in the midst of such extreme misery as was everywhere around us was wholly cut of the question till after mid night, when the ambulance corps (who on this occasion behaved with criminal negligence) removed the wounded to the hospital.
The shrieks and groaning of the wounded that night exceeded anything I ever heard.
Those plaintive cries of wrenched suffering would strike a shuddering horror through the nerves of the most hard-hearted.--Water!
water!! water!!! to slake their burning thirst were the ceaseless entreaties of those poor wrenches.
Some would implode the various regiments to which they belonged to them assistance.
One would call out 145th Pennsylvania and their 17th New Jersey, another 66d New York, and so on. 'For God's sake,' one poor fellow would exclaim, "come and help me!" Another would promise to give his watch and all his money to any one who would assist him to a hospital, whilst others endured their pain in mute silence.
What a pleasure it would have given us to aid in abstaining this suffering is such though was not in our power, with out transgressing our orders.
Every man was then required at his post; none could be spared to go to the rear with the wounded.

The cold shivering of those wounded men, their incessant touching appeals for help, and the low morning of those paining from time to eternity, made up a combination of scud that would make the brain real and the heart of any human being bleed with play.

We — that is that few of us that could contrive to fall asleep during the night — were around a to-day brink by the sound of a volley of musketry coming from the enemy's pickets, which at the time we supposed to be the opening of another day's butchery.
After firing a few volleys in return we were ordered to create firing and lay low. This order, however, was not fully enemy, as many of our sons could not be restrained from shooting from their cage dissolution for fight, and an irregular fling to be kept throughout the day.

That Sunday was one that I rahactessly forget.
I have never on sed a day that awakened in me such painful feelings, nor one when I endured more anxious suspense and greater suffering of both min I and body.
As our regiment chanced to lay on that portion of the field where the fight had raged with the greatest fierceness, and where we sustained the greatest loss, we had the pain of witnessing some of the saddest results on the previous day's on the wet, blood-stained with aching limbs, benumbed with cold, gaining upon the neglected, unburied carcases of our brave fallen comrades, scattered everywhere about us and even among our ranks, and in constant expectation of the renewal of the battle, we passed that gloomy and ever to be- remembered Enchant.

The spectacle which that bloody field covered with hundreds of life loss bodies, lying in every conceivable shape, and disfigured in every form of mutilation presented to the sickened gaze was extremely horrifying end nothing could so well Illustrate the evils and inhumanity of warfare.

div4.head: Letter from an Trish Patriots
div4.p: The "Nation," of Duble, contains a letter from John March our of the Irish exiles of 1843, which is well worth reading:

opener.salute: To the Editor of the baton:

div5.p:
My name has been mentioned in your paper of 1st Saturday as that of a sympathizer with the Southern States in the war which is at present raging in America.
I am a sympathizer with the South; and since the fact is now publicly stated.
I course, with your kind permission to say a few words by way of explaining and defining my sympathy:

Both Pruden are our kindred our friends, our benefactors.
Ireland has no quarrel with either, but is bound to both with the atronqeataties of affection and of interest.
The Irish has contributed largely to the people of the Southern as well as of the Northern States; and the Irish in America, like all other American citizens have to take part in this war with the States of which they happened to be residents.
The most honored and trusted of our political exiles are upon opposite sides — Mitchell is with the South, Meagher with the North. --Williams and Honey have died since the war broke out — the one a soldier of the South, the other leaving his sense in arms for the North.--Those noble hear is new cold in American graves, surely both of from turned with the most intense love for Ireland!

In she it, it is a war between States and populations who are all allied to us by blood, who are all to our eternal gratitude by the munificent chastity with which they strove to feed our people when starving under the English rule, who have all constantly afforded's friendly refuge to our people when driven from their native country by the curse of that rule, who have all shown pity for our suffering under a fore gayoke and given sympathy and encouragement to our aspirations after independence.
To a mere Irish patriot, the honor and prosperity of North and of South are equally dear.
What a spectacle for him — the North and the South contending against each other as the dead inst of themes!
If he feels that his voice can have no influence over the combatants, he may well be a lent while like The O'Donoghue, he gazes up-on the fratricidal conflict "with streaming eye"

But, though such considerations as those have hitherto withheld me from any public declaration as to the right and wrong in this unhappy war they have not prevented me from the free expression of my sentiments among my friends in conversation.
And latterly I have begun to doubt the propriety of keeping silence while strenuous efforts are being made by several persons to represent all the true Nationalists of Ireland as partizans of the North, and to prove that the hopes of our national cause depend upon the success of the North in this war

It was, therefore, with a feeling of relief that I read your article of last Saturday and the letter of your correspondent, who signs him if, "Aldrich American" At all events let the truth be known.
All true Irish Naturalists are not partisan of the North in this war. I do not believe that a majority of them are partisans of the North.
Cousinly. I am not. I desire and hops that the North may never succeed in its attempt to subjugate the South.
I sympathize with my whole heart with the people of the South, defending their homes and liberty against the inviting armies of those who were lately their fellow citizens, to whom they have done no wrong, and of whom they desire nothing but to be allowed depart in peace from the political partnership which they dislike.
Resisting hostile invasion, fighting to save themselves from a yoke of a conqueror the people of the South are defending a that and holy cause, and they are defending it against tremendous odds with such gallantry, endurance, devoted patriotic, heroic virtues as have never been surpassed in the whole history of wars of independence.
A most noble people has there to take its place among the nation, and, springing to arms in defence of its rights, has at once presented before the world a national army so good and beautiful that the proudest of empires might emulate it. In at steamship and military gentus in the courage and discipline that make up for inferiority of numbers and of arms, in the devotedness of the women, in the lefty spirit of national honor that animation a unanimous population the South possesses defences that enthuse her to the victory.
Bit the victory is not always to the righteous cause, nor to the best and bravest.
It may be that the greatly superior resource of the Northern States will enable them in time to the defenders of the South, and to cut legate the country.
I hope not. But victors or vanquished my sympathies are wholly with the people of the South.

I find that I have enlarged so much in the mere expression of my individual feelings, concerning the war between North and South that I must not attempt in this letter to argue the question between them, nor to discuss the beatings of the war upon our Irish national policy.
Indeed is may suffice to say that I agree in everything with your leading article, and also with the letter of "An Irish American"

closer.salute: I am, dear sir, sincerely yours,

div4.head: Semi-official view of mediation.
div4.p: The Washington Republican, generally recognized as an Administration organ, thus expresses itself concerning mediation:

We are confident that we are on the eve of some developments respecting fore gumediation.
There are many straws which indicate how the wind is soon to blow.

The Richmond Dispatch said, some days since, that after the battle of Antietam propositions of peace ought to have been made; that both parties could then have made proposals of this nature with perfect propriety

The N. Y. Tribune has a well considered article upon the subject of foreign mediation, proposing the Swiss Camous as the mediatory power.
It does not object to the French Government making an effort an this direction, but is not so well satisfied with England.
Our people might be satisfied with the interference or mediation of the Swiss Cantons, or even of France or most certainly of Russia, but never with perfidious England, if we can help it.

Other infamous are manifest that something in the shape of interference or mediation is soon to take place.
All this may be premature and unfounded; still we are doubtless approaching a crisis in our national affairs.

We may not be pleased with the complexion our public affairs are assuming; still we know the utter fully of resisting the inexorable logie of events.
If we cannot, or have not, put down the rebellion, we cannot expect nations which suffer much by our quarrel to look on as disinterested spectators forever.

div4.head: Opinions of Yankees abroad
div4.p:
The London correspondent of the New York World, writing on the 20th ult, says he has good reason to believe that Russia and England have reconsidered their replies to Napoleon's mediation proposition.
The "prospect of any legitimate success" on the part of the United States Government, he says, has "grown so much darker of late" that British opinion is inclining to Lord Russell's view, that interference of an effectual character may become the duty of England.
The Paris correspondent of the New York Herald is also in low spirits.
He sees unmistakable signs that France wants to quarrel with the United States, either about Butler or anything else it can get hold of. He says, "What we are all praying for here is the news of a stunning victory to the Northern arms" Perhaps that one at Fredericksburg will suit him.

div4.head: The Emperor Persists in his Project — it has been submitted to Russia and England again.
div4.p: A correspondent of the New York Tribune, writing from Washington, January 31 states:

The news received by the last European mail fully corroborates the statement I made in my last latter concerning the disposition of the French Emperor to follow up his design of mediation and to offer his services to our Government for the settlement of our difficulties.
Several dispatches received by the Federal ministers at Washington indicate such a design, and, if I am not mistaken, Mr. Seward must, by this time, be as well posted on this point as any one of these gentlemen.
But as I have already told you, the proposition will he made in the most friendly spirit, and will carefully avoid any expression of sentiment which might arouse the suspicion or offend the susceptibility of the American people.

According to the information I have received from trustworthy sources all proceedings referring to mediation were suspended, after the answer of England and Russia, till the opinion of the American people on that subject has reached the French Government.
Immediately after, however, a Cabinet Council was convened, in which it was decided that the project of mediation should be forwarded to M. Mercier to be presented to Mr Seward.

But in order to make this measure coincide with the high regards which France professes toward other Governments, it was resolved that the project once rejected by England and Russia should be submitted again to those two powers for reconsideration before forwarding it to America.

To that effect, the Ambassadors of France to London and St. Petersburg were instructed to request Lord Russell and Prince Gorchakoff, solve the time for me based in American affairs had not, as yet in there estimation arrived to have the kindness to state what would constitute, in their eyes, the condition of affairs in which they would deem themselves authorized to offer their mediation, and the time at which the condition would be likely to present itself.

At the same time they were advised to make these two powers understand that the French Government was fully serenaded that the time for mediation was now most opportune, and that it was its intention, should they refuse to consider their first decision to act alone in the matter.

The last news received from Europe states that the English and Russian Governments, sensible of the kind regards of the French Cabinet, have taken the second offer into consideration and are now discussing the propriety of acting conjointly with the matter.

div4.head: The removal of Butler.
div4.p: A correspondent of the N. Y. Port writes:

The Secessionists of Washington point that the Government has already quailed before the threa's of the rebel Jeff Davis.
They claim that the supersedure of Buder was caused partially by the demands of the rebel Government which have been continually urged upon Mr. Line lest summer.
Butler, they say, has been occupied to oppose Jeff, Davis and they point to the fact that General Banks at once-stomped proceedings under the confiscation act as scout as he arrived in New Orleans, these proceedings being counted by the rebel as the most offensive of any under Butler's administration.
Of course, these boasts of the Secessionists are ridiculous.
It is much more probable that the change in the command of the Government troops in Louisiana was made because of a vexations diplomatic quarrel with the French Government.

The complaints of Louis Napoleon have been contentions, and indeed of such an insolent character, that more than one member of the Cabinet is in favor of taking a bold stand upon our rights, refusing any further attempt to pacify a man who seems bent on a quarrel with us. It is rumored here that General Butler will soon have commend of an expedition to Charleston and this is not improbable, for the Government will hardly lay aside so successful a General as has been.
The President is known to be well effected towards the General, and that would hardly be the case if he were to be removed to private life.

The Charleston expedition was alluded to in this correspondence long ago, as if it were about to sail from New York.
Such was at that time the intention of the Government, but for sufficient reasons it was postponed.
There is little doubt that an attempts will be made to take Charleston within a few weeks, and General Butler will make an excellent commander of the land forces engaged in the expedition, especially as he has the prestige of success in such undertakings.
Baltimore and New Orleans are already Inscribed on his fieg, and if he can add the name of Charleston.
It will be enough honor for one man to win in this war.

div4.head: Latest from New Orleans
div4.p:
The dates from New Orleans via New York are to the 27th ult. Ten thousand newly arrived Yankee troops were in camp at Baton Rouge.
The dispatch says:

q.p:
Christmas day was marked by unusual rowdyism Eight persons were arrested for cheering for Jeff Davis, among them an English Lieutenant of her British Majesty ship Vesuvius.
He was taken to the lock up and put into the stocks and fined $50.

div4.head: The Late Gen. T. R. R. Cubb.
div4.p: The New York Observer, referring to the late Confederate General Cobb, of Georgia, who was killed in the battle of Fredericksburg, says:

q.p:
Mr. Cobb was an eider in the Presbyterian Church, and an active member of ecclesiastical bodies, a distinguished author and contributor to the religious periodical literature of the country.
His religious communications have appeared in this paper, and we este med him as an able and excellent Christian gentleman and reholar.

div4.p:
When Mr. Lincoln was elected to the Presidency, we made special exertions to set before the people, especially our readers in the South, the duty of yielding patriotic and constitutional obedience to the Government by whomsoever administered, and we further insisted that resistance to the Government would be rebellion.
Mr. Cobb was the first to resent this doctrine, and to insist upon the light and duty of the South to take immediate measures to deliver its people from the Government of the United States.

When we see such men as Cobb and Hill, and Preston and Jackson, all of them distinguished for their intelligent Christian characters, all of them Presbyterian siders, all of them leaders of the enemy, and all of them men of prayer as well as valor, we are more and more persuaded that our people have not yet appreciated he task they have undertaken in the subjugation of the south.

div4.head: A speech from Captain Semmes.
div4.p: A speech from the "terror of the seas" is a otiosity, and we give the following address from Capt. Semmes, to the passengers on the Ariel when he boarded her:

"Passengers you're safe in our hands You have no occasion to weep on be alarmed.
What do you take us for?
We are all honorable men; rest assured of that.
Did any one harm you as yet? " A voice: "You were near sinking the ship" The pirate continued? "That is only our duty.
We make war on the sea, and the Yankees are our enemies." (More crying and general alarm)

"bequest, you have no cause to be apprehensive of us. No one of our officers or crew will insult you. We are gentlemen.
Do you think we are ruffians who would attack the helpless, or do you imagine we are robbers?
Have confidence in us and we will protect and not injure you. Not an article of your baggage shall be taken from you. You will find we respect private property"

The prize crew applauded the Contains courteous speech, and the passengers soon became more confident.
During the two days in which the Varlet was a prisoner, after this speech was made, the passengers freely fraternized with the poze crew, and some of them even expressed unqualified sympathy with the Southern Confederacy.

div3.head: Confederate account of the battle in Tennessee.
div3.p:
Nothing but Northern accounts of the battle of Murfreesboro' has yet appeared.
An extra from the Murfreesboro' Rebel office, gives us an account from Confederate sources.
The account commences with the battle of Wednesday morning, the real opening of the conflict.
The writer says:

q.p:
The sun rose clear after several days of funeral gloom, rifting the mist which hung like silvery curtains ore the field, dancing and glistening along the serried line of steel, which glittered in the morning light like the sparking of countless diamonds bathing the gay banners which floated in the front with a flood of refulgence, and rifting in golden showers through the emerald fringe of cedars which enclosed the field.
Far as the eye could reach stood the two vast armies, silent and motionless, and it almost seemed instead of foes drawn up for battle to be some brilliant holiday parade; but at length a volley of musketry from the extremes left told too plainly that the work of death had in reality begun, and in an instant afterwards the strife had leaped from point to point, until the whole line from left to centre was one unbroken blaze of fire.

div3.p:
About eight o'clock A. M. the divisions of McCown, Cleburne and Cheatham were ordered to charge.
The enemy were strongly planned in a dense thicket, where the outcropping of the lime stone rock formed a natural fortification.
Swiftly, but with a perfect line, our troops emerged from the skirt of timber in which they had been sheltered and moved across the open plain which intervened.
The battle now become terrific; crash upon crash of musketry stunned the ear; the ground trembled with the thunder of artillery; the cedars rocked and quivered in the fiery blast, and the air was rent with the explosion of shells.
The enemy seemed determined to stake the fortunes of the day upon holding the position which they occupied, and offered a most gallant resistance, but nothing human could withstand the impetuosity of that charge.
A spirit of fury seemed to possess our men, from the commanders down to the common soldiers, and on they swept, shot and shell, cannoneer, grape, and buffets, tearing through their ranks until the way could be traced by the dead and dying Still on they went, overturning infantry and artillery alike, driving the enemy like the hurricane scatters the leaves upon its course capturing hundreds of prisoners, and literally blasting the ground with dead.
Such a charge was never before witnessed.
For two miles through fields and forests, over ditcher, fences, and ravines, they swept.
Brigade after brigade, battery after battery, were thrown forward to stay their onward march; but another volley of musketry, another gleaming of the bayonet, and like their predecessors, they were crushed into one common ruin.

Meantime the brave old Withers was not idle.--His line of battle ran diagonally across an extended field and the enemy had been pouring a murderous fire into his position until driven almost to the verge of madness by the destruction of his men, he threw his division forward upon the ridge occupied by the enemy.
Here was perhaps the bloodiest struggle of the day. The enemy was stronger at this point than anywhere else upon the field, and long and fiercely contended the position.
Directly in front was a wide area of cleared land, and across this it was necessary to advance under the sweeping fire of six batteries; but, with dauntless hearts and seeps as proud as though upon parade his men sprang forward at the word, and marched on in the face of death — Once they wavered, as the enemy poured a perfect half of iron through their ranks but at this moment Bragg named by, the battle fires burning in his eyes, and the fate of nations in his hand — again they rushed upon the foe, shies down the gunners at their pieces, and drove the supporting divisions far back to the rear

div4.head: The, great battle.
div4.p:
In our yesterday's necessarily brief and imperfect account of the sanguinary card of Wednesday, December 31st. we brought the events of the engagement up to nightfall.
the wounded and resting within two hundred yards of the Abolition pickets.
Our right was act so actively engaged, the enemy concentrating and massing his troops in a strong position.
Byrne's battery of seven pieces and Cobb's Kentucky battery were very actively engaged during the afternoon with the batteries of the enemy, but the casualties on our part were small.

Yesterday the New Year dawned upon as with a bright, setting, and propitious fact.
The previous night was intensity cold, and most have seriously affected the condition of the wounded on the field But the gentle soon dispelled the white time of frott that covered the landscape and changed the ley air into a pleasant spring like atmosphere.

Everything was perfectly quiet in front until about 8 o'clock when the cannonading opened on the right centre, and was kept up spiritedly for a short while.
There was another jud. The enemy pressed indisposed to show himself and under the govern of heavy herber it appeared, was making preparations for a retrack.

div4.head: The battle field.
div4.p:
Yesterday presented the usual horrible, and, heat appalling science.
The deed lay scattered in every direction — the Confederate grey uniform and the Yankee blue in fearful proximately after it fever.
At points where our braves had charged and taken the batteries of the foe there were plain evidences or desperate struggle.
But it was quite evident that the dead of the enemy outnumbered ours two to one.
This proportion may seem unreal and impregnable but it was the opinion of every one who visited the field.
Upon every hand were the common debris of a battle — broken gun carriages.
dismantled wagons, plies of dead horsed, scattered accoutrements — all indicating the fearfulness and deep ration of the contest.

div4.head: The Losses.
div4.p:
Our loss in killed, wounded and missing, will sum un 5,000.
That of the enemy is triple, if not five held our own. We captured forty pieces of artillery, and up to last night had paroled forty seven hundred prisoners.
Of small arms, ordnance, camp equipage, etc, we bantered vast quantities.
The prisoners are being rapidly sent South to Vicksburg for exchange, that being in accordance with the previous agreement between Gens Bragg and Rosecrans.
The wounded prisoners, of whom there are a great number, are comfortably housed and being well cared for.

div4.head: The numbers engaged.
div4.p:
Rosencrans's grand army of invasion numbered, according to the lowest estimates, 75,000 men--General Bragg's force we have never yet heard computed at over 40,000, and not more than one-half of those were engaged in the battle.
The disparity in numbers, however, was more than atoned for by the difference in pluck and determination of the two combatants, as well as by the impulses that actuated the men.

Still a walk through the hospitals discovers to the most careless looker-on the saddest and most sickening spectate — a spectacle which we hope will never again mar the quiet and happiness of so many hearthstones in the Confederacy.

div4.head: The wounded and the hospitals.
div4.p:
The spirit of heroic endurance manifested by our troops during the perilous and fearful days and nights of the battle, was worthy of themselves and their holy cause.
But what shall we say of the patience the fortitude, the bravery, even the gaiety, displayed by the wounded.
We saw hundreds of them on the field and in the hospitals, and from not one of them old we hear a single word of complaint or repining.
Many of their wounds were ghastly, many requiring amputation and the severest surgical treatment but all of them bore up with the determined spirit of heroes.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
The body of Maj-Gen. Sill one of the division commanders of the federal forces was brought to town yesterday afternoon, and laid out in the court house.
Gen. Stil was shot through the left eye with a Minnie ball.

Col. Allen, of the 31 Alabama cavalry, was seriously wounded in the hand Col. Marss, of the 17th Tennessee, was also wounded.
Captain Jo. Desha of the 9th Kentucky, was severely wounded in the lead by a fragment of a shell.
He came to town, had his wound dressed, and immediately repaired to the field.
Adjutant Henry M. Curd, of the same regiment was shot through and through by a six pound cannon ball.
Lieut Curd was a nephew of Col. Thomas H. Hunt, and of Gen. John H. Morgan.
It was reported yesterday, that Brig. Gen. W. E. Woodruff, was among the Yankee .

div3.head: The Amenities of war.
div3.p: --A letter in the Richmond Enquirer, from Fredericksburg, gives the two incidents below:

To-day the body of Captain Lawton, wounded in the recent battle a Fredericksburg and carried to an hospital in Alexandria, where he died was returned to our lines sweated by his fond and devoted wife who had gone to purse him but who found him no more when she reached there.
The passage of the body was marked by both sides with the honors due to his rack, end, on the part of the enemy an escort of infantry, with arms reversed, and marching to the sound of martial music, paid the last honors due to the departed brave.
The sight was a touching one and unless grateful to our than it was cared table to the magnanimity of our foe. On our side everything was done decently and it order, under the supervision of that soldier and gentlemen, Gen. Kershaw.

An incident has just come to our notice which deserves to be recorded; It seems that about the time the enemy appeared on the Stafford bills, Young Irvin of Stafford, a member of Gen. Fitzhugh Lee's cavalry, by accident found himself within the enemy's lines, and being unable to extricate himself, was arrested by the Yankees as a spy, and tried end condemned as a spy for execution.
The facts becoming known to Gen. R. E. Lee, that officer knowing the charge to be base leas, at once informed Gen Burnside, who immediately, and to his credit, unconditionally released Irvin.
The City Council of Macon has fixed the license to retail spirituous liquors in that city at $10,000.

div3.head: Say shot.
div3.p:
--About three o'clock on Saturday evening, a lad named Patrick Kearney, who was standing on the basin bank, under the shed in front of Messrs Crenshaw's commission house was shot by some person unknown, the bail passing between the breast bone and rib, and going through his body.
The lad was taken up and carried to his father's house where he now lies in a critical condition.
It was at first thought, from the fact that there were a number of ducks in the basin, and the quarters of the City Battalion are in close proximity to the southern bank, that one of the men had thoughtlessly discharged the load of his musket at the ducks, and that the ball, striking the water obliquely, had glanced, inflicting the on the lad alluded to above.
The officers on being notified of the occurrence made the most right enquiry into the affair, but could learn nothing tending to show that the act had been committed by any of the men belonging to the Battalion.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following deserters were put in Castle Thunder on Saturday and Sunday, viz: R. Whalen, alias J. Kostigan, co G, 16th Miss; G W Hyatt, co A, 28th N. C; Jen Arrington co K, 42d Ve; R E Arrington, co E, 58th V; Gass Hurson co G, 2d Va cavalry; Joseph Vendergrift, co C 10th La; and about forty others.
Michael Driscoll, co D 2d La, was arrested as a supposed deserter, and for attempting to get a passport on false papers to go to Sidney to become a substitute.
Sergeant Mansfield, of co C, 14th La, escaped from Castle Thunder yesterday morning.
He went to the guard and pretended that no was a friend of the Adjutant of the prison, and threatened to have him (the guard) put in the lock-up if he did not allow him to pass.
The guard (James Childress) who permitted the prisoner to pass was subsequently arrested and confined for suffering himself to be imposed upon thus.
The enrolling officer of Luray, Page county, sent down Dan Cromwell, Austin Wickley and G W Jones, as conscripts.

div3.head: Neglect of ministers of the Gospel.
div3.p:
--The minister celebrating a marriage is required by law within ten days thereafter, to return the license to the office of the clerk who issued the same, with an endorsement thereon of the fact of such marriage, and of the time and place of celebrating the came.
The penalty for neglecting this duty is heavy, yet very few comply with the law. All delinquents in the city will be reported to the first Auditor of State by the Clark of the Hustings Court, so that the penalty of the law may be exacted.

div3.head: A good Disinfectant
div3.p:
--The Assistant Provost Marchal to charge of the Military Prison of the Eastern District, has adopted the practice of spreading loam and lime on the floors of the prison, which proved such an excellent absorbent of noxious gasses, that since its introduction, no case of smallpox has been reported.
Be are it was sprickied on the floor, one or more, cases used to be reported daily.
The remedy is worth a trial.

div3.head: Arrival of Ladies and Children
div3.p:
--On Saturday morning the train from Petersburg brought over a large number of ladies and children, who have recently come through the enemy's lines under flag of truce.
Most of them were met at the depot by hundred and friends from whom they have been long and painfully separated, and the happy manifestations at their revision on Saturday morning were truly affecting

--Surgeon H. S. Gaillard the Medical Director on the Staff of Major-General G. W. Smith, has recovered from his recent attack of small pox, and has received leave of absence for entry days.
His duties will continue to devolve upon Surgeon Thos. H. Williams of the regular army.
The Medical Directorship of this Department is a most important position.

div3.head: City small-pox Hospital for Negroes
div3.p:
--A separate Hospital has been opened in Howard's Grove for negro patients, (free or stays) by order of the City Council.
It is now ready for the reception of patients.
The assonance for conveying them will be found at the old small-pox hospital, near Poor House Burying Ground

div3.head: General I will.
div3.p: --This officer is rapidly recovering from the officers of his recent accident, and will in a short time be ready for duty.

div3.head: In the City.
div3.p: --Gen. E. Kirby Smith and staff arrived in Richmond on Saturday.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--The city notice during Saturday and Sunday, made a number of arrests, mostly for trivial offences.
The following parties were held for an examination before the Mayor; William Walkins, for disorderly connect in the Broad Street Theatre; Joseph Tearoey, for having in his possession a lot of old iron tucposed to have been stolen; Charles Williams, a soldier, found asleep in the Market House, was sent to Castle Thunder.

div3.head: Court Procardings
div3.p: Mayor's Court Saturday, Jan. 10th --Joseph H. Goodmen arrested for publishing a pair of blankets worth $10 the property of Chas. W. Spicer, was brought up for examination, and the evidence past fining the charge, he was committed to appear before the Hustings Court.
Michael Murphy was arraigned for getting drunk and acting disorderly in the house of John McPherson, and threatening to shoot the proprietor, He was committed in Defant of $200 security.
Samuel Liggon charged with taking Dr. Warring's horse, on street, was examined and acquitted.
Elchard Barry charged with being engaged with others in assaulting and stabbing Warren L. Story, was committed for a further bearing.
Madison Griffin, charged with forging Jno Griffin's name and getting $15 from Richard Reins was acquitted; but committed in default of $100 security for his good behavior.

The case of Carter Tadlock.
J. P. Thompson, and J. W. Sartin, for stealing $10 from Wm. Rowe, was called, and the witness not responding was continued until Monday, at which time the officers were directed to have on hand all who knew anything of the offence charged against the prisoners.
Martha slave of Mrs. Sally Manford, was ordered a whipping for throwing stones in the street.
George Smith, charged with firing a pistol in the street when drunks, was required to give security for his good behavior.

div3.head: Latest from Vicksburg.
div3.p: The following official Dispatch was received at the War Department on Saturday last:

div4.p:
From latest information I am satisfied the enemy's transports have gone up the river.
Only seven gunboats are between the mouth of the Yazoo river and Miliken's Fend.
Vicksburg is daily growing stronger.
We intend to hold it.

div3.head:
[Associated press dispatches]
important from the Rid Grande.
div3.p: --Late advices from San Antonio, Texas, state that an express from Brownsville had brought information that 4,000 French troops had landed at Matamoras, Mexico, and taken possession.

div3.head:
Results of the campaign in the Southwest.
important official Statements.
div3.p: --The Rebel publishes the following dispatch, from an official scarce, dated Winchester, Tenn., Jan. 9:

q.p: General Morgan's report of his expedition shows two thousand paroled prisoners and several hundred of the enemy killed and wounded and an immense quantity of arms and property destroyed.

div3.p: Fortress report shows 1,500 prisoners, 1,000 of the enemy killed and wounded, and an immense quantity of arms ammunition and stores destroyed, and his whole command splendidly equipped from the captures.

Our operations at Murfreesboro', including the capture of 5,000 prisoners besides 2,000 captured at Bartsvills and around Nashville, sum up 10,000 indeed than a month.
We have slap captured and sent to the rear thirty cannon, 6,000 small arms and 2,000 more in the hands of our troops and 1,000 wagons destroyed and the mules and harness secured.
The enemy's loss in killed and wounded is self mated at 50,000 including seven Generals.

div3.head: From Northwestern Virginia--Banks's expedition.
div3.p: --The Wheeling Intelligencer of the 5th, reports a fight on Saturday between Gen Janklas and Col. Imboden's forces, and the Federal under Col. Washington lasting Saturday and Sunday, and claims that the "rebels had been driven four miles. "
Gen. Milroy is at Winchester.

The New York Herald less by an arrival from New Orleans that Gen. Saints had established his headquarters at Baton Rouge, and had ten thousand men in camp.
More vessels of his expedition had arrived.

div3.head:
[Southern Association dispatches.]
later from the North.
div3.p: --The New York Tribune, of the 8th instant, has the following dispatch from Washington, dated the 7th: "C. L. Vallaudigham, of Ohio, made a speech in the House to-day favoring foreign mediation in American affairs."

The Paris correspondent of the Tribune, under date of the 28th ult., says it is reported that Brouyn de L'Huys has resigned, and says the Cabinet of the French Emperor has, for the present, abandoned the designs of mediation in American affairs.
Advices from New Orleans, of the 28th ult., state that Banks has made Baton Rouge his headquarters.

div3.head: Additional from the North.
div3.p:
--The New York Herald has been received.
It says: To-day we have to record another Fredericksburg affair.
Sherman had been repulsed at Vicksburg, on the 29th ult., with a loss of four to five thousand men and five pieces of artillery.
Among our killed is Gen. Morgan, late of Cumberland Gap. Gen. W. L. Smith was mortally wounded.
We had to contend against an overwhelming force under Gen. Joe Johnston.
Gen. Holmes's army arrived at Vicksburg on the 30th.
Banks's expedition is en route from New Orleans to rent force Sherman, who will remain under cover of his gunboats until a junction of his, McClernend's, and Banks's forces.
Gen. Grant's army is still at Holly Springs, Miss.
The Wheeling intelligencer, of the 6th, reports the defeat of Imboden and Jenkins at Moorefield.

The Yankee Congress has tendered Butler Gen. Twiggs a sword.
Rumor says Butler returns to New Orleans.
A Nashville dispatch, of the 7th, states that the body of the rebel Gen Raines was interred on that day. No demonstration was allowed.
Gold closed at New York on the 7th at 131½ to 135.

div4.head: Foreign news.
div4.p: The Angle Saxon brings London dates to the 24th ult.

Lagard, the under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, made a speech at London.
He said that the principle of his country was non-intervention, and that England sympathised with nations struggling for freedom.
He also said that the Government was right in the opinion that the proposal of France for mediation was fropportune, and that if the English Government had accepted that offer at an importune moment, then, when an opportunity arrived, it would have been lost.

The Paris correspondent of the London Post, under date of the 22d, says: "It is reported that the Emperor has assured the Cabinet at Washington through Mr. Dayton, that France came forward not to favor the North or the South, but in the name of humanity, and for the good of both parties." He says that the Government of France and England continue to be united in their policy towards America and that policy now, as of old, was strict centrality.

The Liverpool Journal of Commerces, of the 22d contains an order to the British agents at the various ports of the West india island that if the Alabama as their ports to prohibit her from costing or taking in providing that the undered to depart as one.
The order further's and that Capt Semmes be informed that, after this notice, should he destroy any merchandise consigned to British merchants in central ships, Her Majesty's Government will take steps to destroy his vessel.

div3.head: From Mexico
div3.p: --(Per Express from Monterey.)--After a severe battle, on the 19th ult., the French army defeated the Mexicans and captured Puebla and Tampico, proceeding immediately towards the city of Mexico.

Commissioner's Sale of Real Estate in the City of Richmond and County of Henrico.--By virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of Henrico county, in the case styled Enders and aid. vs.
Depriest. Administrator, and others, we, the undersigned, as Commissioners, will proceed to sell upon the previous, on Monday, the 9th day of February, 1863 the following valuable Seal Estate in the city of Richmond and county of Henrico, as follows:

list.item:
1st.
Commencing at 12 o'clock M., the Farm known as "Henrico Hill," the late residence of Wm. F. Depriest diseased, on the Osborne turnpike, about a half ruffe cost of the city, and contiguous to Tree Hill, Powhatan, and other estates.
It contains 59 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of an excellent brick Dwelling, Kitchen, Stable, and the usual out-buildings, an excellent Orchard of choice fruit trees, and an abundance of water.
This property is beautifully located, and commends a splendid view of the city of Richmond and scenery on James river and the surrounding country.

2d. Two Tenements and Lots, in the town of Port Mayo, adapted for small sized families.
Sale to commence at 2 P. M.

3d.
And at 3 o'clock will be sold the valuable Wharf property at Rocketts, known as the Steamboat Wharf, and opposite the store of R. O. Haskins, Esq. It fronts Sames river, 149¼ feet, and runs back about 200 feet to Water street.

4th. Two Lots on the intersection of Main and Him streets. Richmond Hill, and designated by the Nos. 161 and 166, in Adams's plan.
They front 132 feet, and run back 165 feet to an alley, a plat of which can be seen at our office in a few days.

5th.
At the same time and place will be sold one third interest in a tract of Land, containing — scres, in Hanover county, on the new Central road, and adjoining the lands of B. W. Roper and others.

div3.p:
Terms.--Gob third cash, (or the whole, if preferred,) the balance at 5 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, satisfactorily endorsed, interest added, and title retained until the further order of Court.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
A. A. Morson, Commis're.
Jno. O. Steger, Commis'rs.
Sale conducted by Jas M. Taylor & Son, Auctioners. ja 6

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of A House and Lot on Valley or 17th Street.--As administrator of George T. Riding, dec'd, I will proceed to sell upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 13th day of January, 1863, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., a very desirable frame house and lot located at the terminus of 17th or Valley street, and near to the old distillery.
It contains six good rooms, and is in good repair.
The lot is of the usual size.
Possession will be given immediately.
Terms--One third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico county, and as such
Adm'r of George T. Riding, decd.
Sale by Jas. M. Taylor & Son. Aucta. de 30

div3.p:
63 acres of Valuable Land on the Osborne Turnpike, in Henrico county, about two miles from the city, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 9th day of February, commencing after the sale of "Marion Hill," advertised by Messrs Morson and Steger, Commissioners, day, at 1 o'clock P. M., a valuable tract of Land, containing 63 acres, and located as above, adjoining the lands of Mr. M. Laughlin, John Farrar, and others, and contiguous to the Tree Hill estate.
Persons destroying to scene a productive market garden would do well to attend this sale.
Terms.--One third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.

Six handsome Building Lots on the North side of Grace, between Henry and Belvidere streets, at Auction.--We will sell, on the premises, on Tuesday, 13th day of Jan'y, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., six handsome Building Lots located on the North side of Grace, between Henry and Belvidere streets, and within the flower garden of Mr. John Morton.
They front 30 feet each and fun back 150 feet.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 4 and 8 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchase — to pay the taxes for 1863.
div3.closer:
Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct.
After the above will be sold on the
40,000 Bricks. Terms — Cash. ja 6

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of very Valuable Real Estate, located on Franklin, Ross, and 14th streets, nearly opposite to the Exchange Hotel — As administrator of Mrs. J. M. Cabell, deceased, I will proceed to sell at public auction, upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 14th day of January, 1863, commencing at 12 M., the very valuable real estate located on the North side of Franklin, Ross, and 14th streets, and nearly opposite the Exchange Hotel.
It fronts on Franklin and 14th streets, a part of which is occupied by the Messrs.
Sutherland and others, and is now commanding a fine rent.
It will be divided into lots to suit the views of purchasers, a plat of which can be seen at the office of the auctioneers in a few days.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest, added, secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
Edward Mayo,
Administrator with the will annexed of
Mrs. J. M. Cabell, dec'd.
Sale conducted by Jas. M. Taylor " Son, Auctioners ja 1

div3.head: Caroline Land for Sale
div3.p: --As Commissioner under a decree (to be obtained) in the Circuit Court of Caroline co., in a suit of Quarried va. Hargrave and wife, I shall proceed to sell, at 12 o'clock, on Tuesday, the 13th day of January, 1863, on the premises, the tract of Land of which the late John W. Quarries died seized and possessed, containing, by recent survey, 733½ acres.

The tract is divided by the road leading from Chesterfield Depot to Chilesburg, about three miles from the former, and will be sold in two parcels--one on the south side of said road, containing 368¼ acres, on which there is (with little repairs) a comfortable Dwelling and all necessary out buildings, with a large platoon of highly improved land; the other, on the south side of the road, containing 365¼ acres, with an old framed Dwelling thereon; both tracts, or pars is, lying well, with a good proportion of creek as bottom lands, well watered, and an abundance of somber.
The whole tract is susceptible of the highest state of improvement, and well adapted to the various crops of when, oats, corn, and tobacco, particularly the latter.

Also, at the same time and place, and under the same decree, will be sold an excellent Mill Site, on the North river, about one mile distant from the farm, with two acres of land attached, long known all be Jericho Mills.

The extensive buildings of corn, wheat, Saw Mill and Cotte Gin are still standing, and the dam (built of one) recently broken by the heavy freshets can be easily repaired, and the mill rendered as profitable as formerly.

Persons dissing to purchase are invited to examine the property before the day of sale, and Wm. T. Quarries, Esq., who lives adjoining, will take pleasure in showing the land, together with a plat of the same.
Terms (which will be accommodating) made known on the day of sale.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I will sell, on the 13th January, at the farm known as "Monterey," on the While Hall road, four miles North of Goochland Court-House, all my Stock Crops, Farming Utensils.
and Household and Kitchen Furniture.
The Stock consists of Horses, Mules, Oxen, Cows, and Calves.
All the negroes on the place will be hired out.

At the same time, will be rented to the highest bidder, for the year 1863, the Farm, containing 350 acres. It has a crop of winter oats seeded on it, and thirty acres fallowed for corn, a good dwelling, and all the necessary out-houses.
Persons desiring to rent will find it to their advantage to attend the sale.
div3.closer:
R. H. Monteiro,
Sale conducted by A. M. Hamilton. de 27--2w*

div3.head: Farm in Hanover for Sale
div3.p:
--The subscriber, being in the employ of the Confederate Government in Richmond, and consequently unable to give his attention to his farm, will offer for sale on Tuesday, the 13th day of January next, on the premises, near daw's Shop, about three miles from Hanover Town, and fifteen miles from.
Richmond, his residence containing about 160 acre, about half of which is cleared and in on titration, and the remainder in woods.
On the Farm is a comfortable Dwelling House, with five rooms; a double kitchen, with four rooms, smoke house, corn house, stable, and carriage-house.
The buildings are all new, having been created within the last five years. The land files well for improvement, and is adapted to the skitivation of corn, wheat, oats, and vegetables, and has now seeded on it about 30 bushels of winter oats.
Has in the yard a good well of water, and a spring on to the house.

div3.head: Hewart House for Sale
div3.p:
--I will sell to the highest bidder, without reserve, on Yesterday, 22d Jan, 1863, my Tavern House and Furniture, in the town of Liberty, situated immediately on the Virginia and Tennessee railroad.
It has been for the past five years, and still remains the regular Noting House for passengers.
The receipts of the House for the past year were 855,000 The House will be sold with or without the to salt the purchaser--

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p: --The bushers Sweet Potatoes, and 300 babels Irish Potatoes, best Peach Blow, in lots to suit purchasers, for family use.--Address, through Richmond P. O.
