div3.head: The handsome affair at Galveston.
div3.p:
Our readers were on Saturday delighted with the telegraphic account of the handsome affair in the of Galveston.
It was one of the most complete and ingenious expeditions of the war, and Gen. Magruder to another laurel.
The of the Harriet Lane is all the more agreeable because that vessel has been quite busy in the war, and was a pet in the Lincoln navy.
She hears the name of the niece of the "Old Public Functionary" who presided at the White House during his Administration.
Though our impromptu fleet was to catch the other vessels she is a prize to boast of. It was first stated that Commodore Renshaw had blown his ship up, and blown himself the better part of his crew up with her. It out that he has not yet laid the world under obligations to him by any such act; but that he "ignominiously" from our little tugs with their bates.
The shooting from behind those bales have been excellent, from the manner in which the decks of the Harriet Lane were cleared.
takes another step upwards in importance, and yet prove its claim to regal power in as well as commerce.

The events of the Southwest increase in interest, and before the winter expires we doubt not there will be stirring news from that direction.
We can not but believe that it will be gratifying to the people of the South.

div3.head: Vicksburg.
div3.p:
Vicksburg still gloriously holds out against attaches from water and land.
The Yankees have had telegraph after telegraph announcing that it had been taken by their forces.
Gen. Grant, who not having done anything to help him to renown in Yankee land, thought he would at least be in advance with good news for the Abolitionists, with that view telegraphed that Sumner took Vicksburg on the 34 inst. His message, though untrue, at least entitles him to the favor of his Government, since he has shown his capacity to that important branch of the public service in this war of subjugation, viz: lying.
We have now the dispatch of Gen. Pemberton, dated the 8th inst., announcing that Vicksburg so far from being in the hands of the enemy had been successfully defended and was daily growing stronger.
The General concludes with the encouraging sentence--"We intend to hold it." The brave defence of this gallant city is gratifying to our people.
That it should stand from against all the exertions of our malignant enemy is a matter of the utmost importance in a political as well as a military point of view.
Therefore, the hopes and prayers of our people are most earnestly bestowed upon her and her heroic defenders.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M., by Mr. Johnson, of Bedford.

A communication was read from J. G. Shorter of Ala., relative to the management of railroads and transportation over them in the Confederate States.
Their exclusive use by Government, it was contended, should cease, and they be left to the people.
Laid on the table, printed, and referred to the Committee on Roads and Internal Navigation.

Mr. Nicholas offered a resolution inquiring into the expediency of building a bridge over Green river, in the county of that name; Mr. Queen of relieving citizens of Caroline and Spotsylvania whose slaves had been stolen by Yankees, and refunding taxes paid on some, and also granting relief to citizens of Port Royal whose houses had been robbed and burned by Yankees; Mr. Pate, of reporting a bill appropriating money in the relief of Virginia soldiers in the Confederate States Army or State Line, whose counties are in by the enemy in such manner as to prevent them from hearing from home.
The joint resolution offered by Mr. Collier, directing the Governor to get passports for the members during the session was called up, discussed, and adopted.

Mr. Armstrong, of Hampshire, offered a lengthy preamble and resolution relative to the depredations of the Yankee army in Western Virginia, under Gen. Milroy, recommending that the commanding General, when caught, be hung, and that the sum of $100,000 be appropriated to further this and other measures of retaliation.
At one o'clock the Senate went into secret session, and on the doors being opened adjourned to meet Monday at 12 o'clock.
House of Delegates.--The House met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Speaker.

Mr. Fleming offered a resolution that so much of the Governor's Message as refers to magistrates and other officers who have taken the oath of allegiance to the United States Government, be referred to the Committee of Courts of Justice.
Agreed to.
Mr. Burks submitted a resolution, as follows:

Whereas, The General Assembly, by joint resolution, adopted on the 19th day of May, 1862, declared "that it is the sacred and patriotic duty of every good citizen of the Confederate States, not under duress of the enemy, to receive in his business transactions the notes of the Confederate States, and to refuse to receive them must depreciate their credit, and will tend to deprive the Confederate Government of the means of defending our liberty and independence, and such conduct cannot be too strongly denounced as most effectually offending aid and comfort to the public enemy. Therefore.

Resolved, That the special committee, appointed to consider the resolutions touching the legal tender of Confederate notes, inquire into the expediency of punishing by suitable penalties any citizen of the Commonwealth who shall refuse to receive the Treasury notes in discharge of any debt or obligation for the payment of money.

Mr. Magruder presented a resolution that the Committee of Courts of Justice inquire into the expediency of so amending the Stay Law as to afford protection to securities.
Agreed to.

Mr. Bradford of Clarke, called up his resolution offered yesterday, in relation to the payment of slaves impressed into the service of the Confederate States, and not returned to their owners by reason of having escaped to or captured by the public enemy.
Adopted.

Mr. Mouldin moved a reconsideration of the vote adopting the resolution, and the motion being agreed to, be moved to amend the resolution by ing out the words 'by reason of having escaped,' &c., so that the resolution should read, "The General assembly of Virginia request our Representatives in Congress to use their efforts to procure the age of a bill by Congress providing for the payment for slaves impressed into the service of the Confederacy and not returned to their owners." --After some discussion, the whole subject was referred to the Committee on Courts of Justice.

Mr. Woolfolk offered a resolution, which was agreed to, instructing the special Committee on slaves and Free Negroes to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill for the gra removal of free negroes in this Commonwealth, and to recommend the same action by the States, thereby removing from the Confederate States this injurious population.

Mr. Nopkins, of Rockingham, presented a read to instruct the Committee on Banks to inquire into the expediency of so amending the charter of the Bank of Rockingham as to enable it to increase its continent fund twenty per cent.

A resolution, offered by Mr. Wilson, of of Wight, in relation to supplying the people of that county with their quota of salt, after, several amendments and considerable discussion, was committee, to a special committee of seven.
Mr. Mouldin, of Charlotte, called up the bill entitled "an act to limit the cultivation of tobacco and to increase the production of grain;" read the first time and ordered to a second reading.

Mr. Beakerville offered a resolution that the Senators of Virginia be instructed, and the Representing requested, to use their efforts to secure a repeat of the present tariff laws, so as to allow the importation of goods free of duty.
Laid over under the rule.
On motion of Mr. McCamant, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Twelfth regiment.
div3.p:
--The 12th Virginia regiment, since it commenced active service in the battles around Richmond, has lost 319 men, as follows: killed 44; died of wounds, 15; died of disease wounded 16 The following are the contributions of this regiment to the Fredericksburg sufferers.
Field and staff, $75; Company A.
(Petersburg City Guards,) $40; Company B.
(Petersburg Graye,) $62, Company C.
(Petersburg Grays,) $49, Company D.
(Lafayette Guards,) $39; Company E. (Petersburg Rifles,) $71.75; Company F.
(Sugar Grays,) $75.75, Company G.
(Richmond Grays,) $104, Company H.
(Norfolk Juniors) $63; Company (Mercury Grays,) $10, Company K.
(ber Rifles,) $50.50. Total, $639.

div3.head: The Green question Settled.
div3.p:
--The fact of the British Government having agreed with the other protecting Powers to respect the protocol by which Prince Alfred is prevented from accepting the threes of Greece appears to have given satisfaction to the French Government and the Cabinet of Russia.
The three Powers have agreed to recommend to the Greeks as their ruler Ferdinand, of Portugal, father of the present of that country.
Ferdinand acted as Request of Portugal during the minority of his son. He is a of the royal house of Saxony, forty-six years of age, and very popular.

div3.head: Dead.
div3.p:
--Col. Geo. Walton, a son of one of the signers of the old Declaration of Independence, died in Petersburg, Va., a few days since, aged 73 years. He was formerly Territorial Governor of Florida, and later in life the Mayor of Mobile.
He was the father of the well known Mad. Octavia

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpaeil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: On the 8th instant, by the Rev. Mr. Duncas, Mr. W. A. Singleton, of Richmond, and Miss M. V. Morgan, of Manchester. *

div4.p: On the 10th inst., at 3½ P. M., of wounds received in the second battle of Manassas, Charles Curtis Carter of Co. B, 1st Va. reg't, in the 28th year of his age.
His funeral will take place from the residence of his brother-in-law, (Mr. Abner H ard,) this day at 11 o'clock. Friends of the family are invited to attend. *
At his residence in Chesterfield county, on the 11th of January, 1863, Thomas Macon Trabue, in the 25th year of his age.
His friends are invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, on Tuesday, 13th inst., at 12 M.
On Saturday, January 10th, 1863, at 10 o'clock A. M, of pleurisy, ÆNeas Montague aged 62.
His funeral will take place from the Second Presbyterian Church, (Dr. Read's) this morning at 19 o'clock. *
On Friday night, 9th inst., at half past 9 o'clock, after a lingering illness, of dropay, Alfred K., youngest son of Ann E. and J. L. Monby, aged six years seven months and nine days.

lg.l: Farewell, my dear Alfred; my dear Alfred,
I bid you a long adieu;
Around God's bright and zzling throne,
I hope to meet you there.
Like the fairest rose of summer,
Alfred bloomed and Alfred died,
Oh, how long this world without him.
He was our joy and pride.
Yes, we love him, love him dearly,
And could never control.
The bright waves of affection.
Which often us roll. *

div4.p: In the city of Richmond, January 19th, 1863, (Saturday forenoon,) after an of seven days, of deptheris, Herbert Fletcher, infant child of L. H. and Mobile F. Lively, formerly of Williamsburg, Va., aged 7 months and 22 days.

lg.l: Lay him gently in the coffin.
Wrap the cold, white shroud around him;
Fold his arms across his breast--
Our darling Herbert has gone to rest.
Oh, our hearts are sad and lonely,
As we weep above thy bed,
And one home is lone and dreary,
For our darling Herbert *

div4.p:
At Warrenton, Va., on the 3d November, 1862, private George W. Corley, son of H. S. and Corley, of Louisa co., Va., aged 35 years.--He was wounded at the second of Manassas on the fifth of August, 1862.
He left behind one son and a great many friends to mourn their loss.

lg.l: brother, like the fairest rose of summer,
Georgia become and Georgie died.
Oh, the world without him,
Yet he was our joy and pride. *

div4.p: On the 10th of January, at the residence of David H. Minson, Ida Love, daughter of and Sarah M. Meredith, aged 11 months.
Farewell, my baby, I hope to meet you where parting will be no more. *
At St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum, on Saturday, 10th instant, Betty Mabony, in the 18th year of her age. *
On the 10th instant, at his residence, in this city, Hampton Janes, in the 57th years of his age, leasing a large family and numerous friends to mourn their loss. *

div3.head:
Camp 38th Virginia Reg't,
January 7th, 1863.
div3.p:
to the people of Mecklenburg county, Va.--Please accept our heartfelt thanks for your very liberal donation of clothing, shoes, and blankets.
It is cheering to think that we are not forgotten by our fellow-citizens; that while battling for liberty and all that makes life desirable, there are those who are mindful of our comfort; who voluntarily deprive themselves of the few luxuries left them by the invader, and place another sacrifice upon the after of their country, by endeavoring to furnish the absent soldier with something to protect him from the cold blasts and pelting storms of winter.
This donation is honorable alike to the citizens and soldiers of Mecklenburg, and well worthy of her prestige for liberality and patriotism.

We also tender our grateful acknowledgments to the ladies of Mecklenburg.
Wherever there is suffering, woman is ever the first to sympathise and alleviate.
In our present struggle for liberty she has exhibited a patriotism as lofty, and a spirit as indomitable as ever characterized the history of any county.
We are proud to know that the daughters of Mecklenburg have equalled, if not surpassed, their sisters in fulfilling woman's highest mission.
We assure them that their offering will be gratefully appreciated, and that many a fervent "God bless you" will go up from the stout soldier's heart, in behalf of the fair, patriotic ladies of this good old county.
We despair of adequately expressing our thanks.
To think of your kindness, is inspiring; and when the battle comes, it will infuse courage in our hearts and strength in our arms to strike for liberty, for Virginia, and for Mecklenburg.
div3.closer: Company "G," 38th Va. Reg't. ja 12--1t*

div3.head: Resolutions of thanks.
div3.p: --At a meeting of the "Old Dominion Guard," (company K, 9th Virginia regiment) held at their camp, near Fredericksburg, on the night of the 25th December, 1862, 1st Sergeant Henry C. Hudgins in the chair, the following preamble and resolutions were adopted:

Whereas, the refugees of Portsmouth and Norfolk, now residing in Charlotte, N. C., together with a number of the citizens of that town, ever mindful of our wants, have so opportunely and generously contributed to our comfort necessary articles of clothing, shoes, etc.

Resolved, That we, as a portion of the recipients, do hereby tender them our sincere and heartfelt thanks, assuring them that their kindness will ever be remembered by those who have thus been timely protected from the pinching cold, and dreary blasts of winter.

Resolved, That these mementoes, assuring us as they do, that though absent, we are not forgotten by those we love, and for whom we struggle, tend greatly to alleviate our hardships, enliven our spirits, and encourage us in the performance of our duty.
Resolved, further, That these proceedings he published in the Richmond Dispatch, and the papers of Charlotte and Raleigh, N. C.

Notice. To families from the District of Columbia and the State of Maryland, who have come to Richmond, expecting to find their husbands and relatives here, and have been disappointed in meeting or finding them, may be benefited by addressing a note through the Post Office, "Box 1037."

div3.p: --The first annual meeting of the Stockholders of the Piedmont Railroad Company will be held at Danville on Wednesday, 21st Jan., 1863.

div3.head: To the Voters of Richmond.
div3.p: --I respectfully announce that I am a candidate for your suffrages at the election to be held on the 15th day of the present month, for a Clerk of the Circuit Court of our city.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --All persons whose Liquor was seized under martial law prior to April 22, 1862, are hereby notified to appear before a board, consorting of Major E. Grilswold, Major J. C. Maynard, Captain G. W. Alexander, and Captain R. M. Booker, on Wednesday, January 14th, at 12 o'clock M, at the Provost Marshal's office, corner of Broad and 9th streets.

div3.head: To the friends of the 15th Reg't Va. Vols.
div3.p:
--Major B. H. Wood having promised his transportation, I give notice that I will attend to the delivering of all boxes properly marked and left at Messrs. H. H. Whillock & Son's, corner of 18th and Cary streets, during this week, for the 15th Virginia Regiment of Infantry.
Persons desiring to send had best take advantage of this opportunity.
Some of the boys need underclothing, and those that do not would be glad to have their accustomed Christmas presents.
div3.closer: Very respectfully, Robert H. Whitlock, Va. Life Guard. ja 7--4t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The general meeting of the Stockholders of the Bank of Virginia will be held at their Banking House in the city of Richmond, on Monday, the 12th January, 1863.

The law provides that no officer or director of the Bank shall vote as the proxy of a stockholder in any election of Directors or officer of the Bank, nor shall any proxy be valid which shall have been executed sixty days before the time of election.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs 1st Va. Reg't.
December 30th, 1862.
div3.p:
Notice.--Any information of Serg't Henry Sullivan, of Company "C," (Montgomery Guard,) 1st Reg't Va. Volunteers, will be thankfully received by the officer commanding and also the company.
He was wounded at the battle of Manassas, August 30th, 1862, and sent to one of the hospitals in Washington, and has not been heard of since the 15th of November, 1862.
Supposing him not living at the present time, any person knowing anything of him will confer a favor by addressing a few lines to
div3.closer:
Lieut James Hallinan,
Company "C," 1st Reg't Va. Vols.
Kemper's Brigade. ja 12--3t*

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p: --George W. Phillips will return to Richmond as soon as he can, as his family awaits him here.

div3.head: Notice to creditors.
div3.p:
--Creditors entitled to claim under schedules A and B in the deed of trust from J. B. Bragg, and wife to Wm. F. Taylor and R. R. Howison, Trustees, dated April 9th, 1857, and under schedules A, B, and C, in the deed of trust from Wm. Bootwright to the same Trustees, bearing the same date, both recorded in Richmond hustings Court, are hereby notified and requested to present their claims, properly authenticated, to the undersigned, at his office, on Governor street, in order to a settlement and distribution according to law and the terms of said deeds.
A dividend of 68.85 per cent, has been ascertained, distributable to creditors in schedules B and C, respectively, in said deeds, from proceeds of sales.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of Real Estate and two Negroes, in Henrico county, at Auction this day.
div3.p:
--We invite particular attention to the sales this day by John A. Hutcheson, administrator, of valuable Real Estate and Slaves, to take place as advertised.
For particulars refer to the auction column of this paper.

div3.head: United Presbyterian Church.
div3.p: --An adjourned meeting of the Pew Owners of the United Presbyterian Church will be held at the Church on Wednesday, the 14th instant, at 4½ o'clock P. M.

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p: --We have for sale a magnificent 7 octave Piano in carved Rosewood case, a really superb instrument, to which we invite the attention of those in want.

div3.head:
Office Richard and Pet'g R. R. Co.,
Richmond, Va., Dec. 24, 1862.
div3.p: Dividend Notice.--The Board of Directors save declared a dividend of six per cent. on the Capital stock of this Company, payable on and after the 31st, at the office of the Company, in the city of Richmond, to all persons who may be stockholders on that day, or to their lawful attorneys.
The Books of Transfers will be closed until the 1st of January, 1863.

div3.head: Wanted--Confederate money
div3.p:
--In exchange for my Hotel or Restaurant, at the corner of Cary and Virginia streets, near the Danville depot together with its entire stuck of Soda and Bedding.
Furniture fixtures, and appointees of every description necessary to the comfort and economy of customers.

I have long conducted this establishment, with entire success, and can its continuance to any one who will devote proper attention, and shall be pleased to show the premises to any one who may desire to lease or rent it, and purchase privately the entire Household and Kitchen Furniture, which I will sail low, being determined to retire from the business.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To hire, a colored Boy, from 18 to 20 years of age true or slave, to wait on a Surgeon in Gen. A. P. Hill's division, now on camped hear Fredericksburg.
For one that is willing to go and make himself useful a liberal price will be paid.
Inquire at my residence, on 24th, between Broad and Marshall streets, between the hours of 1 and 5 o'clock P. M.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A situation as Teacher in private family or public school, to teach the usual English branches and Music, by a young lady of same experience.
The country preferred if not over 50 miles from Richmond.
Address " Gee."through the Dispatch office, stating particulars, etc.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Ten more Girls from 12 to 17 years of age, to work in our Factory on Clay, between 9th and 10th streets. Also, two experienced Book Binders.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A white Girl, to do housework in a small family.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Thos. Wm. Stage,
Corner Main and 9th streets. ja 12--1t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Youth, of unexceptionable character, to take charge of an office.
Apply to "Merchant," Box 244, Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --George W. Phillips to come to Richmond as soon as possible, as his family is here.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen, on the night of the 8th of January, from the stable of the Bowling Green Hotel, in Caroline county, a sorrel Horse, 15 or 16 had a high, blind in one eye, and has a large soar on his wethers, which appears to have been the result of a fistula, in chewing grain he twists his head to one side; has marks of the saddle on his back, has been in the cavalry service for the last six months; walks slow trots, and canters well.
Any person returning this horse either to the camp of the 10th Virginia Cavalry, Gen. W. H. F. Lee's brigade, or to Mr. Joseph Bix's livery stable, on 10th street, between Main and Cary will receive the above reward.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--On Saturday morning last, on Broad, between 1st and 8th streets a draft colored Serlin wire, Ports Monnaie, containing $39--one $20 and one $10 Confederate note; the remainder being in notes of smaller denomination.
The finder will be liberally rewarded by leaving the same at G. A. Baldwin & Co.'S, 13th between Main and Cary sts.

div3.head: Lost.
div3.p:
--A Certificate of Deposit in the City Savings Bank, No. 2,830 dated Dec'r 27, 1861, in the sum of $234.06, issued to Richard B. Sample, has been misplaced.
This is to forward all persons against bargaining for the said certificate.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--On Thursday last, between the Richmond Arsenal and Jackson street, a Memorandums Book, containing my Exemption Papers and a Detail to work in the Richmond Arsenal.
For their return to the Laboratory the finder will receive the thanks of the loser.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p: --On the upper part of Franklin street, on Thursday evening, a Black Lace Veh. The finder will be suitably rewarded on leaving at at Mrs. James's, corner of Franklin and 3d sts.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Kemper's brigade,
Pickett's division, January 8, 1863.
div3.p:
Twenty-five Dollars Reward.--Strayed or stolen on the 21st of December, one large bay Horse; paces fast; left eye out. No other marks remembered.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me at these headquarters.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen--$150 Reward.
div3.p:
--On the night of the 6th January, three Horses; a small thoroughbred sorrel, seven years old, slightly away-backed; a dark bay Mare, and a light bay Horse, were stolen, or strayed from Ransom's Division, while camped near Falling Creek, between Richmond and Petersburg.
To any one delivering these horses to the Postmaster of Richmond $150 reward will be paid, or $50 for either of them.

div4.head: Description.
div4.p: One small sorrel Horse, (thoroughbred,) 7 years old, slightly away-backed; when you approach him appears very spiteful, but go directly up and he is not at all so.
One dark bay Mare, (small,) about 8 years old, has a small white spot upon her back, caused by saddle long mane and tail; also, has a running sore under her jaw; walks, trots paces, and canters well.
One light bay Horse, his mane is rather inclined to go upon the left side of his neck than upon the right, he is about 7 or 8 years old; walks, trots, and canters well.

div3.head: Lost Child.
div3.p:
--Strayed away from our office, on the morning of the 9th instant, a small Negro Boy, about 7 or 8 years old, of dark color, had on when he left a dark suit of clothes, shoes somewhat worn, and is named Frederick.
We will give a suitable reward if delivered to me, or for any information leading to his recovery.
div3.closer:
Clopton & Lyne
Office corner Wall and Franklin sts. ja 10--2t

div3.p:
Ten Dollars Reward for each Cow. Strayed or stolen, from my residence, on 17th street, two Cows--one a red Buffalo, with a slit in both cars and a small white star on her forehead, the other a red and white Cow, with a piece of her, left horn, a slit in her left ear, and a short tall, and was believed to be with calf when she left.
The finder will be liberally rewarded for their return, or any information and can get them.
div3.closer: John McDONOUGH. No. 10 Pearl street. ja 10--3t*

div3.head: Ten Dollars Reward.
div3.p: --Strayed or stolen, from my store, on last Saturday three weeks, a dark bay Mare, with both bind legs awaited, blind in left eye, and white star in her forehead.--The finder will receive the above reward by leaving her at my store, on 14th st.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p: --Several single gentlemen, members of Congress or others, can obtain Board in a desirable locality by addressing "F. S. M.," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Several single gentlemen can procure Board and Lodging, and also a few day Boarders, in a genteel private family, on moderate terms, on 9th street, beyond Leigh, in a few minutes walk of the Departments, by applying immediately.
Price can be known by applying to

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p: --A few gentlemen can secure Board by applying at Mr. Woodard's, on Grace, between 3d and 4th sts. A few day Boarders can also be accommodated.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The subscriber wishes to make an arrangement with a responsible person to cut into Cord Wood (upon shares) timber already felled, sufficient to make 500 or 600 cords of oak and pine wood.
Apply at my office, southeast corner of Marshall and 7th streets, between the hours of 2 and 4 o'clock P. M.

div3.head: Leather, Leather.
div3.p:
--The undersigned have this day formed a co-partnership under the style and firm of Johnson, Henderson & Eglinton, for the purpose of manufacturing and finishing all kinds of Leather.
We have taken the house No. 43 Old street, where all work entrusted to us will be executed in the best possible manner.
We shall employ none but the best workmen, and respectfully solicit the patronage of the public.

div3.head: Fredericksburg Theater.
div3.p: The above beautiful establishment will reopen
Tuesday Evening, Jan. 1863.

With an array of talent unequalled in the Confederacy.
The Theatre, since the sacking of it by the Yankee vandal horde, has been thoroughly renovated, and, regardless of expense, new nery Decorations, and Appointments have been added, making it one of the first class buildings of entertainment.
N. B.--Ladies and Gentlemen, of acknowledged talent, wishing engagements, will make application to the Stage Manager, W. C. Talbott.

div3.head: Fashionable dancing Academy.
div3.p: By Prof. J. St. Maur Singham.
No. 65 Main Street, between 14th and 15th, entrance private.
Days of Tuition.--Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.
Hours.--For Ladies, 10 A. M.; Children, 4 P. M.; Gentlemen, 7 ½ P. M.
Practicing Parties every Wednesday, at 8 o'clock P. M.
Guitar and Flute.

Lessons taught on the Guitar and Flute.
Orders may be left at P. H. Taylor's made Store, Main street, or at the Academy during the hours of tuition on the above days.

div3.head: Metropolitan Hall.
div3.p: Buckley & Co.'S Opera House.
The most fashionable place of amusement in the city.
"What everybody says must be so, and everybody says that
is the funniest man living," and that"
Buckley's
Nightingales
is the best company in existence.
Come and see for yourselves.

div3.head: Grand Military Amusements.
div3.p: --Capt. Bragonime's Drill and Fencing Room, on 10th street, two doors below Main, and over Copp's Pistol Gallery, is open day and night.
Small Sword and Broad Sword Fencing; also, Bayonet Fencing taught.
Cavalry and Artillery Sword Exercise taught inside of Eve lessons.
Fencers can have a Fencing Match at any time.

div3.head: For Drewry's Bluff.
div3.p: The steamer A. H. Schultz, Capt. D. J. Hill, wharf at Rocketts daily, at 12 o'clock--returning at 3 o'clock P. M.
fare for the round trip, $1.

div3.head: A Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --A liberal price will be given for a Substitute, who will report at once at the office of John H. Glimer, Esq., on 14th street, between Main and Bank streets.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted
div3.p: --For a Georgia Regiment, apply to the undersigned, at the Boarding House of Mrs. Barnes, street, near 9th.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted
div3.p:
--For a member of the 3d Alabama regiment.
None but an acceptable man need apply.
Address "J. M.," box 1,132 city Post Office.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--To a good home a capable Housemaid and Sea Estress-- quick, and of good character.
Inquire of
div3.closer:
Thos. J. Bagby,
No. 8 Wall st., St, Charles Hotel. ja 12--2t

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p:
--Privately, a young Woman, with four Children; and one man Cook.
Also, for hire, three young Girls.
Apply at Miss Charlotte Temple's residence, corner of Main and Adams streets.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--On Saturday, December 10th, 1863, my servant, Clara.
She is about 12 years of age, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and of very dark complexion, had on when she left a light spring called.
She may be making her way towards Fredericksburg, where her father now is. I will give a reward of $20 for her delivery to me.
div3.closer:
Emanuel Raymond, Butcher,
Near General Hospital No. 1. ja 12--3t*

div3.head: Long time ago.
div3.p: Two Persons and Ne'er a Church, Publicans and Patriots, Flush Times, A Fish Story, The Colored Aristocracy, and other capital sketches, will be found in a readable book called "Richmond in Bye Gone days." Price only 50; by mail 80

div3.head: Saddle Horse for Sale
div3.p:
--A splendid bay Horse, suitable for an officer, in fine condition, and warranted perfectly sound in every respect.
Will be shown by Mr. Earnest, at the Staff Stables, opposite the Capital.

div3.head:
Good Bacon,
good Butter.
div3.p: At Robert Hill's Commission House,
Corner of Bank and 12th sts.

list.item: 10 fickins No. 1 Butter, and numerous other goods.

div3.head: Sweet Potatoes
div3.p: --A consignment of very superior North Carolina Sweet Potatoes for sale by
div3.closer: W. B. Green, 137 Cary st. ja 12--1t*

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--Furnished Rooms.
Also, Boarders taken.
Apply at the north corner of Grace and Foushee sts.

div3.head: Administrator's Notice.
div3.p:
--Being anxious to settle up the estate of Amson Richards as soon as possible, I request that all persons indebted to it will at once come forward and settle.
All claims against the estate, if properly authenticated, will be paid upon presentation to the undersigned, at Williamson & Co.'s auction room, on Governor st., one door above Franklin.

Thirty Dollars Reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery to me for each of the following named deserters, viz: Thos. Gibson, Jas. O'Hara, Jas. Ryans, and Wm. Millson, substitutes from in or about Richmond, Va.; also, Wm. A. Peters, Jno. Flora, Samuel H. Salley, Andrew Jackson, Calch Kinsey, Elies Sink, Jessee Simmons, Meador Simmons, Jas. Simmons and G. W. Simmons, from the county of Franklin, Va.; also, Thos. D. Wilkerson, from the county of Halifax.
Va.

The following named men will either immediately report in person or send authority for their absence to these headquarters, else they will be advertised as deserters and treated as such upon delivery to me: Corpl Wm. S. Tucker, Privates Jos. H. Crank. Benj. Glasscock, Henry T. Powell, Wm. Reese, Abber E. Reese; from the county of Halifax, Va; also, G. W. Amos, Jos. Amos, Spencer Amos.
Jas. Bally Israel and Nosh Sink, from the county of Franklin, Va; and the following named man assigned to my company from 5th Va. battalion: B. F. Bennett, B. F. Buckner, J. C. Bally, H. L. Gray, J. M. Garner, Wm. H. Harris, E. W. Moore, S. H. Pale, H. T. Pearson, E. C. Person. J. W. Robinson, S. P. Robinson, Wm. A. Reese, T. H. Taylor. T. H. Tillar, J. H. Watson, T. G. Woodroof, J. J. Williams, N. T. Williams, L. S. King, from the county of Greensville, Va. If any of the above named men have died or been discharged, I wish to have the fact reported, that mistakes may be avoided in future.
div3.closer:
James O. Chappell,
Dept. co. F, 54d Va. Reg't.
Camp near Ga Station.
R. F. & P. E. R, Jan. 5, 1863 ja 12--

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p: --Thirty Dollars Reward will be paid for
John Collins, an Irishman, with based eyes black halt, dark complexion, 5 feet 10 inches high — a deserter from date's brigade.
div3.closer:
W. H. Fitzgerald.
Co. F. 21st Miss. Reg't. ja 12--3t*

div4.p:
--Deserted from Company A, 30th regiment Virginia infantry, while near Martinsburg private. Tyson.
son is about 5 feet inches high, black hair and eyes, dark complexion, and by occupation.

He is now in Culpeper county.
Deserted from Co. A., 39th regiment Virginia infantry, May 24th, 1862, private Edward J. Kiley.
Said Kiley is about 25 years of age, auburn hair, blue eyes, and about 5 feet 6 inches high.
A reward of thirty dollars will be paid for the arrest of said Kiley.
div4.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Jno. K. Anderson.
Lieut. Comm'dg Co. A. 30th reg't Va.

div4.p:
Deserted from Company A, 30th regiment Virginia infantry, July 4th, which stationed near Petersburg, Va., privates Wm. McDOUGLE W. R. Trery, R. H. Powell, and H. Ram Nings.
Said Wm. McDougle is about 27 years of age, dark hair, dark eyes, 5 feet 10 inches high, and by occupation a W. B. Farry is about 27 years of age, dark hair, black eyes, 5 feet 11 inches high, and by occupation a farmer.
R. H. Powell is 23 years of age, black hair and eyes 5 feet 3 inches high, and by occupation a farmer. --Hiram Johninge is about 23 years of age, dark hair and eyes, 5 feet 9 inches high, and by occupation a laborer.
A reward of thirty dollars will be paid for the arrest of either of the above parties, so that I can get them.
div4.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Jno. K. Anderson.
Lieut. Comm'dg co. A. 20th reg't Va. inf'y.

div4.p:
Deserted from Company A. 50th regiment Virginia infantry, while detached in Richmond on Government work, private Wm. H. Skinner, about 30 years of age, black hair and eyes dark complexion and by occupations right.
Also, private Richard Saunders, about 30 years of age, dark, hair and eyes, dark complexion, 5 feet 10 inches high, and by occupation a carpenter.
The reward of thirty dollars will be paid for their arrest and delivery to me, or confined so that I can get them.
div4.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Jno. K. Anderson.
Lieut. Comm'dg co. F, 30th reg't Va. inf'y.
Camp near Fredericksburg December 1st, 1862. ja 10--2t*

div3.head: Thirty Dollars Reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid for each of the following men, Deserters from my company:

Wm. Buliott — Deserted on or about the 24th of September, 1862, 5 feet 8 inches high; dark hair; gray eyes, good complexion; marked with India ink on the back of each hand and arm, and also his breast; is about 27 or 28 years of age; was formerly in the U. S. marine corps, and is supposed to be within the Yankee lines.
His home is in Alexandria, Va.

James H. Sullivan — Deserted on or about the 9th of November, 1862, 5 feet 8 inches high; dark auburn hair, inclined to curl; dark, hazel eyes fair complexion; high check bones; 23 or 24 years of age; supposed to be within the Yankee lines in Stafford county, near Falmouth.
Samuel Foulks, 5 feet 9 inches high; light hair, blue eyes; florid complexion, slow of speech; supposed to be in or near Fredericksburg, Va.
H. Tarlton, 5 feet 9 inches high; dark hair; eyes hazel color, and blinked; fair complexion, slow of speech; supposed to be at or near Nell Macouls, near Spotsylvania C. H. Va.
T. Minor, 5 feet 9 inches high; light hair; blue eyes; fair complexion, about 24 or 25 years of age; supposed to be at the Catherine Furnace, Spotsylvania county, Va.
div3.closer:
Hogh S. Doggett.
Captain com'g company B.
30th reg't Va. infantry. ja 10--2t*

div3.head:
Hdq'rs 30th Reg't Va. Inf'y.
December 1, 1862.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars Reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these headquarters of each of the following named persons deserters from Company I, 30th regiment Virginia infantry:

Richard Conner, deserted Nov'r 10th 1862, is about 5 feet 6 inches high; dark hair; blue eyes and fair complexion.
Reuben Bowler, 5 feet 6 inches high, dark hair; and eyes; dark complexion, and a little cross-eyed, deserted Nov'r 10th, 1862.--Thos. Skidmore, about 5 feet high; black hair, blue eyes, and fair complexion; Wm. Ennis 6 feet high; black hair; gray eyes, and dark complexion, deserted his company about the 6th of Oct'r, 1863.
Harion Sullivan, 5 feet 4 inches high, auburn hair; blue eyes, and fair complexion.
The above named persons are all resistants of Stafford county, Va.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
John S. Bureuss, Lieut. com'g Co. I.
Camp near Fredericksburg, Va. ja 10--2t*

div3.head: Camp near Fredericksburg, Dec. 1, 1862.
div3.p:
Thirty Dollars Reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these quarters of private W. H. Cawood, who left Richmond for camp on or about the 13th November.
He is about five feet ten inches high, fair complexion, light hair, gray eyes, stout built, by employment a fisherman.

Also, $30 reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these headquarters of private James Roach, who left his company (which has since expired on or about the 9th of September.
He is about five feet eight inches high, fair complexion, light hair, gray eyes, about built, and by occupation a fisherman.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison, Com'g Reg't. M. L. Price, Lt. Com'g.
Co. K. 30th Va. Reg't. ja 10--2t*

div3.head:
Headq'r 30th Reg't Va. Vols.
December 1, 1862.
div3.p:
Thirty Dollars Reward — Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these headquarters of Joseph W. Beasley, private in company 11, 30th regiment Va. Vols, (infantry,) who deserted his company on or about the 18th October, 1862.
The said J. W. Beasley is about five feet high, complexion fair, eyes blue, and by occupation when enlisted a brick layer.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Thos. H. Brooke,
1st Lieut. Com'g Co. H, 30th Reg't Va. Vols. ja 10--2t*

div3.head:
Headr's th Reg't Va., infantry,
Camp near Fredericksburg, Dec. 2d, 1862.
div3.p:
Thirty Dollars Reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these headquarters of private James E. Deshazo, of Co. F, 30th Va. Infantry, who deserted his company at out the latter part of July, 1862, while in camp near Petersburg, Va. Said Desirazo is about 35 years of age, six feet high, dark hair and eyes, and dark complexion.
He resides in Caroline county, Va.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Jno. S. Burruss, Lt. Com'g
Co. F, 30th Va. Infantry. ja 10--2t*

div3.head:
Headq'rs Ewell's Cavalry escort Co.,
Camp near Port Royal, Jan. 9, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserters.--The following men have deserted from my company.
The usual reward known by Government will be paid for their return to me:
All others now absent are notified to report immediately to camp, or they will be treated as deserters.

div3.head: Thirty Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted from Company D, 39th Virginia regiment infantry, the following named persons: Private Jno. Fulcher, John L. Sacra, Wm. A. Lumsden, and Wm. J. Luck.
Said Fulcher is about 5 feet 10 inches high; light hair, and gray eyes.
Sacra is about 5 feet 10 inches high; auburn hair, and blue eyes.--Lumsden is about 5 feet 8 inches high; auburn hair, and gray eyes.
Lick is about 5 feet 4 inches high, light hair, and light gray eyes.
The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of each of the above-named members of company D.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. A. T. Harrison.
Benj'n G. Rawlings.
1st Lieut. com'dg company. ja 10--2t*

div3.head: To the creditors of Joseph Brummel.
div3.p:
--The undersigned will pay to the creditors named in schedule "B" of the trust deed, (notes for wheat, &c.,) 88 per cent of the principal of their debts on and after the 13th January, 1863.
Those who have not received their dividend of 12 per cent., declared in May, 1861, will also be paid that dividend.
The notes must be presented when payment is to be made.
div3.closer:
Wm. B. Isaac. Trustees.
Andrew Johnston, Trustees. ja 10--4t

div3.p:
--A Wheeler & Wilson Sewing Machine for sale in good order.
Apply at the corner of 19th and Marshall sts.

150 kegs assorted Nalls, for sale by

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p: Two small Brick Tenements, on the West line of 2d, between Broad and Marshall streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 15th January, 1863, at 4½ o'clock P. M., the two excellent Brick Tenements located as above--one occupied by Lieut. De Zouche, and the other by Mrs. Shead, at the annual rent of $338. These tenements are admirably well located for private dwellings or for stores.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a crust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1863 to be paid by the purchasers.

Valuable Lot on the East ride of 4th and North line of Jackson street, for Sale at Auction. --Will be sold at auction on the premises, on Thursday, the 12th January, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M., the large lot located as above adjoining the property of Jno. T. Sub Esq., fronting 90 feet running back on the line of Jackson street 125 feet to an alley twelve feet wide.
Terms--One-third cash; balance at four months. The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
ja 7 Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.

P. S.--After the foregoing sale, will be sold a Lot on the cast line of 4th, between Jackson and Duval streets, 60 by 125 feet, adjoining the property of Mrs. Fleming Griffin.
Also, a Lot on the west line of street, to Baker street by 125 fall.
Terms as above.

div3.head: By & Ga. Auctioneers.
div3.p: Large Sale of Furniture at Auction.--On Thursday, the 15th instant, commencing at 10 o'clock, we will sell at our warehouse, second floor, a large assortment of Furniture part of which is in fine order and of quality, consisting in part of--
The Pianos will be sold at 12 o'clock.

div3.head: Large Sale of Dry Goods at Auction.
div3.p: --On Wednesday, the 14th, commencing at 10 o'clock, we shall sell a very large and well stock of Fresh Dry Goods, comprising the largest and most desirable assortment by as this and consisting in part of the following choice Goods, viz:

list.item: 500 pieces Black and White and Fancy Prints;
50 pieces White, Red, and Gray Flannels;
500 doz. Green & Daniel's Black Spool Cotton;
200 lbs. Dark Blue, and W. B. Patent Threads,
50 reams Note, Cap, and Letter Paper;

div3.p: --Also.--

250 pieces Dress Goods, many of them fresh and beautiful styles consisting of splendid French De Laines, Plaid Doplins Paris Stripes, Black De Laines and Alpacal, Highland Plaids Manchester and Pacific De Laines, Debegas, Gray Doplins, &c., the whole to be closed without reserve.
This sale will be composed exclusively of Dry Goods, and no other articles will be offered.

div3.head: By Williamson & Co., Aucts.
div3.p: Sale.--As Curator of the late Alexander McKay, I shall sell at auction, upon the premises corner of Main and 26th streets, on Wednesday next, the 14th January, at 10 o'clock A. M., all the Stuck and Implements such as are generally used by consisting of--

list.head: &Also.&

Lot of Cabbage, 10 or 12 cards of superior Pine Wood;

we will sell at our salesroom, Governor street, one door above Franklin.

list.item: Rocking Chairs, Manageny and Pine Tables;
Marble top Centre Table and elegant Mirrors,

div3.head: 40 cords Pine Wood at Auction.
div3.p: --We will sell, on Wednesday, January commencing at 6 o'clock P. M., at James of excellent Pine Wood, in lots of five and ten cords.

div3.head: By Alexander Nott, Auct'rs.
div3.p: Special Sale of Books, &c — Will be sold at Auction at my store, on Wednesday, January 14th, at 10 o'clock, 300 volunteer Poetical, Theological, and Miscellaneous Books, 20 reams Letter Paper.
Also, a small for Faints, ets, Cold and Sliver Watches, Jewelry,

Furniture, Dry Goods, Clothing, &c. Will be sold at auction at my store on Tuesday, January th at 10 o'clock, a lot of Bedsteads, Mattresses, Tables, Stoves, sts., Clothing, Blankets, Shoes, and Glassware.

div3.head: By Auctioneers.
div3.p: Will be sold at the C. S. Lot, Bacon's Quarter Branch, on Friday, the 18th instant, commencing at 10 o'clock.
125 Horses and Mules
Also, a lot of Wagons, suitable for tation use and hauling wood.

div3.head: Receiver's Sale of Tobacco.
div3.p: --Pursuant to a dearer of the District Court of the Confederate States of America for the Eastern District of Virginia, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, to the highest bidder, for cash, on Tuesday, the 13th day of January, 1863, at the Tobacco Exchange, in the city of Richmond, five hogsheads Tobacco.

div3.head: By Sumner & Bureaus, Aucts.
div3.p:
Large Sale of Valuable Furniture.
On Tuesday, the 13th inst., at 10 o'clock, at our warehouse, we will sell a very large and valuable collection of first class Furniture, consisting in part of--

list.item: Feather Beds; hair, Shuck, and Cotton Mattresses;

div3.p: and many other desirable articles of Furniture and housekeeping goods.
--Also.--
an invoice of Crockery and Glassware, consisting of--

list.item: 1 elegant French China Banner Set, etc.

div3.head: By Thomas W. Auctioneer.
div3.p: Sale of Hardware, &C.--Having determined to close the Hardware business, I will sell at auction on Wednesday next, 15th inst., commencing at 10 o'clock, my remaining stock, consisting, in part, of--

list.item: 70 doz pairs Butt and T. Hinges,

div3.p: Files, Chisels, Braces and Bits, Augers, Chains, Candlesticks, Fenders, Cinder Shovels, handsome Fire Sets, Looking Glasses, Waiters, Tea Trays, Roes, Rakes, Pencils, Needles and many other article in demand.

A. B. Clarks.

div3.head: Two Horses for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on Saturday morning, the 17th inst., at the horse auction lot, on Council Chamber Hill, two bay Horses.
They are to be sold for livery, and on account of whom it may concerns.
div3.closer:
Jos. K. Kix,
Proprietor American Stables, ja 9--td

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & Son, Auctioneers.
div3.p: Administrator's Sale of Real Estate, Ten Negroes, and other Personal Property, at Auction. --As administrator of Jno. Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 12th day of January, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., in the following order, the valuable real estate and personal property, to wit:

list.item:
1st.
The tract of land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run turnpike, in Henrico, about 8 miles West of the city of Richmond.
It contains about 63 acres of land well improved.--The improvements consist of a comfortable dwelling with two rooms, barn, stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the fruit trees.

2d.
Another small tract, containing 4½ acres of land, near to the above.

3d.
A tract of land on the Deep Run turnpike, 6 miles from the city, on which there is a comfortable dwelling, containing four good rooms, and the usual out-houses.
This tract will be sold at 3½ P. M.

div3.p: After the sale of the first named tract (say commencing at 12 o'clock M.,) will be sold Ten Likely Negroes, containing of men, boys, women, and children.
Also, a large lot of Household and Kitchen Furniture.

Terms--For the real estate, one-third cash, the balance and 12 months, for negotiable with interest added, and by trust deed.
If desired, the whole purchase money will be received.
For the slaves and other personal property, cash will be required
div3.closer:
John A. Hucheach.
Late of Henrico county, and as such
Adm'r of Ford, dec'd.
Sale by Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. de 20

div3.head: By Richard thern, Auct'r.
div3.p: On Monday, the 12th inst., at 10 o'clock, at my store, I will sell at auction about 2,000 Bacon, sent from commission merchants, to close consignments, 12 boxes Tobacco, 10 boxes Cigars; 4 boxes Salt, 10 barrels Flour, Rice in bags, &c.
Boots, Shoes, &Also, a lot of heavy Boots and Shoes, Slipper, Suskins, and Ladies and Guitars, Ladies' Collars, Stockings Socks, Gloves, &c.
Flated Ware Gold Watch, &c.--At 11½ o'clock I will sell a fine Gold Watch and Chain, 18 fine, I richly Posted Ten of 5 pieces; 1 Coffee Fitcher, 1 Communion Pitcher, and

Furniture — After the above, I will sell a lot of Furniture, consisting of 3 superior Cooking Stores, 3 handsome Parlor Stoves, and 5 Sorrel Stoves, 40 Chairs, Mattresses Safes, Tables Carpet, Reg. &c.
Family Horse Buggy and Hardness.--At 12 o'clock I will sell a good Family Horse and second band Buggy-- nearly new, and in good offer.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p: Nine Valuable Tenements in Manchester on Bull and Hainbridge streets for Sale at Auction. --Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Monday, 12th January, 1863, at o'clock P. M., in the order advertised the following valuable Tenements, viz:

list.item:
1st.
The Tenements on the north side of Bull street, near to Mayo's bridge one of which is occupied by Mr. Alexander Butler as a store and dwelling, and considered an excellent business stand.

2d.
The excellent Framed Tenement on the south side of Bull, between Allen and Burrows streets, now occupied by Mrs. Vernell.

3d.
Those six Framed Tenements at the corner of bridge and Burrows streets, occupied by Mr. and others, adjoining the residence of Capt. W. W. Wrisiger.
These Tenements are well built and are in good order.
The corner Tenement is a large one containing 7 or 8 rooms.

div3.p: The particular attention of persons disposed to invest in real estate is called to this sale.
Terms.--One third cash, the balance at 6 and 12 months, for with interest added, secured by a The taxes and insurance for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: By Dickinson & Co., Aucts.
div3.p: I will sell at the Auction Rooms of Hill, Dickinson & Co., on the 19th of January, 1863, one Woman (Mary) and Child, to the highest bidder, for cash, on Commissioner of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond.

div3.head: Free Negroes for Sale at Auction
div3.p: In purchases of an order of the Hustings of the city of Richmond made at the December term of said Court, I will sell on Monday, the 11th day of January, 1863 (that being Court day,) in front of the City Hall, to the highest bidder, for cash, the following Free Negroes, convicted of grand larceny, and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery, viz; Sarah Edward Patterson and Dray.
Sale at 1 o'clock A. M.
I shall on Monday, January at Chesterfield (that being Court day,) a valuable Woman and four Children.

div3.head: By & Apperson,
div3.p:
Excellent Framed Tenement, on the Fast line of 18th near to Venable street, for Sall at Auction.--Will be sold at auction on the on Wednesday, January 14th 1863, at 4 o'clock the excellent Framed Tenement located as above, new occupied by Mrs. Me Donough.
The house has good rooms, including basement, and in remarkably well

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Excellent Framed Dwelling,
div3.p:
in Sidney, on Temple street, near to Camp Winder, and beautiful Lot in Harvis's plan, on Nelvidero street, for sale at Auction.--At the of Mr. John Joyce we shall sell at auction, on the premises on Tuesday, the 13th January, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M., the Hence and located as above, near to Camp Winder and nearly opposite the late residence of Mr. L. H. Dauce.
The left has a front of 55½ feet and a depth of 175 feet. The Dwelling has 3 rooms, kitchen and a stabin, and a well of good water.
Possession given in a few days.
Also on the same time and place will be sold the most beautiful in Harvie's plan on the West line of Balvidero street, fronting 60 feet running back 145 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.

Terms.--Cash.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the

div3.head: By D. F. Booth, Auctr.
div3.p: Furniture at Auction.--Will be sold at the auction rooms, 202 Main street, between 9th and 10th, on Thursday morning, January 9th, commencing at 10 o'clock, a splendid lot of Furniture, of a family declining housekeeping, consisting of--
Together with a lot of Cane and other Chairs Mattresses, Pillows and Bolsters, Sheets, Pillow Cases, Blankets, Red Spreads, Cooking Stove and Fixtures, &c. Also, 8 Carpets.

D. F. Booth, Auct'r.

D. F. Booth, Auct'r. ja 9--3t*

Geo. W. Doswell, Com'r

Sale by Dickinson & Hill, Auctioneers. ja 8--t6*

div3.head: Farm for Sale.
div3.p:
--A nice little Farm, containing acres, about two-thirds cleared, with 40 acres of feet land, and the balance in good oak and pise wood lying in the county of Prince Edward, on Buff Creek, six miles from Faresville three from the Court-House, and one mile from Hampden Sidney College.
The vements consist of a new frame dwelling house hull and in the best manner, with six kitchen, smoke house, carriage house, all new, good negro houses, stables, &c., convenient to churches, and as fine as any in the state.
This farm can be bought for what it before the war.--Any one to make on investment or to educate their children at oblige and then their after the war will do well to purchases.
For further information inquire of James A. Davis, Lynchburg, or address Wm. H. Kennedy. Prospect Depot who will them at and take them to see it.

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--In Hanover county, 8½ miles from Richmond, and 3½ miles from Mechanicville, on stage road from Richmond to Tappahannock, on Beaver ½ creek, a Farm, containing 222½ acres of land, about 140 cleared, balance Heavily wooded, some beautiful meadow land.
The Buildings are in good order — Dwelling house with six rooms, Bark, Stables, and other necessary out houses.
For further particulars apply to the subscribing residing as Mechanicville.

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p:
--I have for sale a of Counters, Drawers, &c., of a large Drug Stare.
A bargain can be had by application.
